{"uri": "8096410547", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "09:17:19", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T09:17:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T09:16:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.sanews.gov.za/south-africa/sa-commemorates-world-malaria-day", "title": "SA commemorates World Malaria Day", "body": "The National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) said it was forging ahead with supporting the national Department of Health to eliminate locally acquired malaria in South Africa through several activities.\n\nAccording to the NICD, Africa bears more than 90% of the global malaria burden, with one child dying every minute from malaria - a preventable and treatable disease.\n\nEach year on April 25, the NICD joins the global community in recognising World Malaria Day.\n\nThis year's theme will focus on 'Accelerating the fight against malaria for a more equitable world'.\n\nThe NICD said that in South Africa, cases of malaria are associated either with local transmission of the malaria parasite in areas of the Limpopo, Mpumalanga and KwaZulu-Natal provinces, or exposure to malaria parasites in travellers to other endemic regions returning to South Africa.\n\nAccording to a report on malaria case trends based on notifications captured through the Notifiable Medical Conditions Surveillance System (NMC-SS) from September 2022 to August 2023, the majority of malaria cases in South Africa came from the malaria-endemic province of Limpopo.\n\nData reveals that 5 813 cases were recorded of which 2 845 were logged in Limpopo.\n\nMeanwhile, Gauteng reported the second-highest number of cases, all of which were associated with imported malaria.\n\nIn contrast, the national public health institute said KwaZulu-Natal reported the lowest number of infections sitting at 424 among the endemic provinces.\n\n\"In KwaZulu-Natal, nearly all of the cases reported were imported cases, supporting claims that the province is edging closer to halting local transmission of malaria,\" the NICD explained.\n\nAs per the NICD, peaks in malaria notifications typically follow periods of increased national and international travel to malaria-endemic regions.\n\nData also shows that economically active young males, especially those aged between 20 and 39 years, appeared to be the most at risk population group, a trend observed in other low transmission areas.\n\n\"These findings emphasise the importance of targeting young males with messaging during major holidays and strengthening malaria test-and-treat activities along shared international borders.\"\n\nThe NICD's Centre for Emerging Zoonotic and Parasitic Diseases supports the National Department of Health in eradicating locally acquired malaria through several activities.\n\nThese include contributing to malaria surveillance for accurate monitoring of the occurrence of malaria in South Africa and providing technical support to provincial malaria control programmes.\n\nThe centre monitors insecticide resistance in malaria mosquitoes, screens for antimalarial drug and diagnostic resistance, teaches and trains on various aspects of malaria, and supports improved quality control for laboratory testing for malaria.\n\nThe team also leads innovative research, including investigating novel ways to control malaria mosquitoes and assessing the impact of environmental pollutants on malaria mosquitoes lifecycles and their ability to transmit malaria parasites.\n\nFrequently asked questions (FAQs) and further information on malaria prevention is available on the NICD website www.nicd.ac.za. - SAnews.gov.za", "source": {"uri": "sanews.gov.za", "dataType": "news", "title": "SAnews"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8096014533", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "04:36:38", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T04:36:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T04:36:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/world/2671328/", "title": "Accelerating the fight against malaria for a more equal world - ExBulletin", "body": "On this year's World Malaria Day, WHO has joined forces with the RBM Partnership and other partners to highlight the critical importance of advancing health equity, gender equality and human rights in malaria responses worldwide.\n\nI would like to begin by acknowledging the tremendous contribution of national malaria programs and their partners in facilitating and advocating for malaria prevention and control measures, especially in support of marginalized and hard-to-reach populations. Our collective work will contribute to a more equal future.\n\nDespite these efforts, malaria remains a serious global health challenge that takes its heaviest toll on the most vulnerable. Young children living in the poorest families in sub-Saharan Africa are disproportionately affected by the disease. Pregnant women, refugees, migrants, internally displaced persons and indigenous peoples are among other groups at higher risk of contracting malaria.\n\nMany people continue to miss out on the services and information they need to prevent, detect and treat malaria, particularly those who experience disadvantage, discrimination and exclusion. We must strengthen and increase our support for these populations - not only is it our moral duty, but it is the best way to get back on track to achieve our global malaria targets.\n\nSince 2017, WHO has reported annually World Malaria Report on a stalling of progress towards critical objectives of the global malaria strategy, particularly in countries bearing a high burden of disease. In 2022, malaria killed an estimated 608,000 people worldwide and there were 249 million new cases.\n\nWithout a change in the current trajectory, many people, especially those living in situations of greatest poverty and vulnerability, will continue to die from malaria - a disease that is preventable and treatable.\n\nHealth disparities are hampering efforts to reduce malaria in the countries hardest hit by the disease. Through the High Burden to High Impact (HBHI) approach, catalyzed in 2018 by WHO and the RBM Partnership, countries have tackled malaria by identifying those who suffer most and making a concerted effort to reach them with personalized packages of interventions and services. .\n\nLast month, Ministers of Health from HBHI countries demonstrated further political commitment by signing the Yaound\u00e9 Declaration, in which they pledged to accelerate efforts to reduce malaria deaths in their respective countries.\n\nIn signing the declaration, the ministers committed to address \"sustainably and equitably\" the challenge of malaria. They recognized the importance of addressing the root causes of stalled progress in malaria control, including low access to and inadequate quality of health services, as well as gender and financial barriers within households.\n\nMinisters also committed to the goal of ensuring that all populations at risk of malaria consistently receive the appropriate tools, including those living in hard-to-reach areas and in conflict and humanitarian settings.\n\nHealth disparities are also undermining efforts to complete the last mile on the road to malaria elimination. In many countries with a low malaria burden, cases of the disease are concentrated among vulnerable, hard-to-reach populations such as mobile and migrant workers, refugees and indigenous communities.\n\nReaching, engaging and empowering these populations with targeted, gender-responsive and culturally sensitive interventions and services is an important strategy for achieving our collective vision of a malaria-free world.\n\nResponses to malaria can be strengthened by increasing investment in research and development of new tools that benefit all people at risk of the disease, and especially the poorest and most marginalized populations.\n\nThe tools recommended by WHO should be increased evenly and sustainably. If widely implemented, several innovative tools recommended in recent years -- including dual-active bed nets and malaria vaccines -- will increase health equity for populations at risk of malaria.\n\nWHO remains committed to supporting countries to ensure that any recommended tools are used effectively. Between 2018 and 2023, WHO supported more than 30 countries in the strategic use of data for decision-making and in adapting interventions at sub-national levels.\n\nIn response to ever-increasing financial constraints, WHO, in consultation with national malaria program managers and partners, has also developed a set of guiding principles for prioritizing interventions in resource-limited settings to achieve maximum impact; we will publish these principles in the coming weeks.\n\nAccess to quality health services can also be improved through gender transformative programs that address the many barriers women and girls face, such as lack of decision-making power within households and lower levels of literacy.\n\nThe fight against malaria can be accelerated through a commitment to universal health coverage (UHC). Everyone should have access to the health services they need - when and where they need them, and without facing financial hardship. WHO recommends the reorientation of health systems towards primary health care, which is considered the most comprehensive, equitable and cost-effective way to achieve UHC.\n\nAs you may have seen, the Global Malaria Program launched a new operational strategy ahead of World Malaria Day. The strategy notes that all efforts to combat malaria must be rooted in the principles of health equity, gender equality and human rights to ensure that people in vulnerable situations are protected and have access to quality health services.", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8096100188", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "05:50:34", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T05:50:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T05:50:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.streetinsider.com/Press+Releases/Resolve+and+resources+needed+to+end+Malaria+as+a+public+health+threat/23112924.html", "title": "Resolve and resources needed to end Malaria as a public health threat", "body": "After-hours movers: Cadence Design Systems, Cleveland-Cliffs, Riot Platforms, and more\n\nPacific Friends of Global Health has strongly endorsed Australia\u00e2\u0080\u0099s $30 million commitment to malaria elimination in the Pacific, announced to mark World Malaria Day.\u00c2\n\n\u00c2\n\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cThis is a strong commitment that builds on solid progress combating malaria in our region,\u00e2\u0080\u009d said Pacific Friends chair and Burnet Institute CEO, Professor Brendan Crabb AC. \u00e2\u0080\u009cAustralia, and in particular Foreign Minister Penny Wong, is showing strong leadership on malaria. This welcome commitment reflects the world\u00e2\u0080\u0099s urgent need for greater resources and resolve to meet the goal of ending this ancient scourge as a major public health threat by 2030.\"\n\n\u00c2\n\nThe $30 million investment includes $5 million to James Cook University to support Pacific countries to strengthen surveillance and control of mosquito-borne diseases like malaria, dengue and zika. A new $8 million partnership with non-government health organisation PATH, in a consortium with Australia\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Burnet Institute and the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research, will also help develop new diagnostic tests targeted to our region.\n\n\u00c2\n\nThe Commonwealth is also partnering with the Medicines for Malaria Venture, providing $17 million for the development of new malaria treatments including medicines suitable for use in pregnancy and for children.\n\n\u00c2\n\nGlobal progress in combating malaria is under threat due to conflict, climate change, and increasing resistance to insecticides, with nearly half the world's population at risk - including 2 billion people in our region. In 2022 alone, there were 10 million cases in the Asia-Pacific Region - a two million increase from 2021. Globally, 608,000 people died from malaria, the majority among children under the age of five. Pregnant women and young children are particularly vulnerable to the disease.\n\n\u00c2\n\nDespite these challenges, the world is making significant strides. In the last two decades, the Global Fund, which is the main funder of malaria eradication programs, has invested more than US$17.9 billion in malaria control programs, providing 65% of all international financing for such programs. Since January 2021, the Global Fund has increased malaria grants by an average of 23%.\n\n\u00c2\n\nProfessor Crabb said: \u00e2\u0080\u009cHighly effective tools exist to prevent malaria ravaging families and communities. These include insecticide-treated mosquito nets, seasonal malaria chemoprevention for children under five, preventive treatment during pregnancy, indoor residual spraying, and robust testing and treatment protocols. We know these methods work and when they are equitably distributed, they are powerfully effective.\"\n\n\u00c2\n\nIn 2022, the Global Fund distributed 220 million mosquito nets, covered 8.5 million structures with indoor residual spraying, provided seasonal malaria chemoprevention to 37.1 million children, and ensured that 14.6 million pregnant women received preventive therapy for malaria. Additionally, 321 million suspected cases of malaria were tested, and 166 million cases were treated.\n\n\u00c2\n\nScientific innovation is driving further progress. For example, new mosquito nets using two insecticides are dramatically more effective than single-insecticide nets. Moreover, Gavi the Vaccine Alliance began rolling out the first ever and long-awaited malaria vaccine, whilst a second vaccine received recommendation for use in late 2023. These vaccines, when deployed alongside existing tools and as part of comprehensive national malaria control plans, are helping to accelerate action to get back on track to defeat the disease.\n\n\u00c2\n\nInvestment in community health workers who bring lifesaving malaria prevention and care services to those who need them most is also highly effective. These investments benefit the health system more widely, as community health workers are trained to diagnose and treat diseases beyond malaria and to incorporate malaria prevention measures alongside other health care services.\n\n\u00c2\n\n\"Today, a child dies from malaria every minute,\u00e2\u0080\u009d Professor Crabb said. \"By harnessing the power of new and existing tools to fight malaria and ensuring equitable access to game-changing innovations, we can prevent infections and deaths and get closer to ending malaria by 2030. We urge the Australian Government to maintain its commitment to achieve this goal.\"", "source": {"uri": "streetinsider.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "StreetInsider.com"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-04-335541521", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "18:01:08", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T18:01:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T15:06:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.africa.com/world-malaria-day-united-states-u-s-mission-uganda-strengthens-fight-against-malaria/", "title": "World Malaria Day: United States (U.S) Mission Uganda Strengthens Fight against Malaria", "body": "Today U.S. Mission Uganda observes World Malaria Day to reaffirm our commitment to support Ugandans in the fight against malaria. Through the U.S. President's Malaria Initiative (PMI) and other collaborations, we are working closely with local partners to eliminate malaria and improve health outcomes.\n\nLaunched in 2005, the U.S. President's Malaria Initiative (PMI) supports implementation of malaria prevention and treatment measures as well as cross-cutting interventions. PMI's 2021-2026 strategy titled \"End Malaria Faster\" envisions a world free of malaria with the goal of preventing malaria cases, reducing malaria deaths and illness, and eliminating malaria in PMI partner countries.\n\nToday, Ambassador Popp attended World Malaria Day events in Namutumba District to highlight U.S. government investments in malaria prevention and response. This work is implemented by the U.S. Peace Corps and the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) through partners Holistic Initiative to Community Development (HOLD) and John Snow Inc. (JSI). Working through host organizations, Peace Corps Volunteers reach vulnerable households through evidence-based interventions.\n\nDuring his visits across Uganda, Ambassador Popp has engaged with community leaders, healthcare workers, and local residents to discuss the challenges of malaria control and explore innovative solutions. He has observed firsthand the impact of U.S.-funded initiatives, such as the distribution of insecticide-treated nets and the provision of life-saving treatments and diagnostics.\n\nMalaria remains a significant public health concern in Uganda, causing illness and death, particularly among children and pregnant women. U.S. Mission Uganda has been a key partner in providing technical and financial assistance to Uganda's malaria control efforts.\n\nThrough the U.S. President's Malaria Initiative and USAID in Uganda, we have:\n\nsupported the training of 4,000 Ugandans in indoor residual spraying.\n\nprotected 3.2 million residents in 770,000 houses from malaria with the distribution of 2.5 million mosquito nets.\n\nsupplied 5 million testing and treatment kits to health facilities.\n\nThese efforts have led to a significant reduction in malaria cases and deaths.\n\nU.S Mission Uganda is proud of the work we are doing with our partners to create malaria-free households where no child or pregnant woman dies because of malaria; where communities and health facilities have the medicines they need to save lives; and where there are enough trained health workers to properly diagnose and treat each Ugandan infected with malaria.\n\nThis World Malaria Day is an opportunity for us to reflect on the progress we have made together and to recommit to the actions needed to reduce malaria deaths and eliminate malaria as a public health threat.\n\nDistributed by APO Group on behalf of U.S. Embassy in {"uri": "8097201659", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "17:43:42", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T17:43:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:42:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://dailypost.ng/2024/04/25/malaria-prevalence-in-edo-30-govt/", "title": "Malaria prevalence in Edo 30% - Govt", "body": "The Edo State Government has said the malaria prevalence rate in the state is 30 per cent based on a 2020 report.\n\nDAILY POST reports that Dr Williams Iyekekpolor, the manager of the Edo Malaria Elimination Programme, disclosed this to newsmen on Thursday in Benin while speaking on the occasion of 2024 World Malaria Day.\n\nIyekekpolor, who said the state is working to achieve the WHO's zero malaria target by 2030, noted that the state had a progression of malaria reduction from 50 per cent to 30 per cent within two years.\n\n\"The World Health Organisation has set the goal for malaria eradication by 2030, and Nigeria is expected to achieve zero malaria by this time frame. Nationally, Nigeria still accounts for 25 per cent of malaria prevalence, while in Edo, the prevalence is 30 per cent as of the 2020 report.\n\n\"So we believe that between 2020 and 2030, we will be able as a state to achieve zero malaria, as we had a progression of malaria reduction from 50 per cent to 30 per cent within two years,\" he said.\n\nThe malaria elimination officer, who spoke on the theme of 2024 World Malaria Day, \"Accelerating the Fight Against Malaria for a More Equitable World\" with the slogan \"Change the Narrative; Do the Needful,\" said a collective effort is needed to fight against the disease.\n\nHe said the state government is currently offering free malaria testing and treatment using the rapid diagnostic test in all its Primary Health Care centres.\n\nHe also added that the state insurance scheme has a close-to-free malaria treatment plan for patients registered in the scheme.\n\n\"If you go to our outpatient departments, in our hospitals, you will discover that 80 to 85 per cent of the patients are malaria-infected,\" he added.\n\nHe advised residents to sleep under long-lasting insecticidal nets, ensure a clean environment without stagnant water and seek prompt treatment when sick with malaria.\n\nHe disclosed that a road walk across the city centre, as well as free malaria screening and treatment, were part of the activities lined up {"uri": "8095803793", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "00:37:40", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T00:37:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T00:37:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.news18.com/lifestyle/world-malaria-day-2024-theme-history-key-facts-and-quotes-8861583.html", "title": "World Malaria Day 2024: Theme, History, Key Facts and Quotes - News18", "body": "World Malaria Day is observed across the globe on April 25 to spread awareness about the deadly mosquito-borne disease.\n\nWorld Malaria Day is observed across the globe on April 25 to spread awareness about the deadly mosquito-borne disease. The day highlights the efforts to end malaria and to educate people to prevent its spread. On World Malaria Day 2024, the World Health Organisation (WHO) joins the RBM partnership to eradicate malaria and other partners in highlighting barriers to health equity, gender equality and human rights in malaria responses worldwide - as well as concrete measures to overcome them.\n\nAccording to the latest report from the WHO, progress has been made in reducing malaria, still too many people are at high risk from the disease. People living in the most vulnerable situations including pregnant women, infants, children under 5 years of age, refugees, migrants, internally displaced people, and indigenous peoples continue to be disproportionately impacted.\n\nClimate change and humanitarian emergencies are displacing populations making them vulnerable to the disease and hindering progress on achieving the vision of a malaria-free world.\n\nWHO recommends prompt diagnosis for anyone with suspected malaria. If Plasmodium falciparum malaria is not treated within 24 hours, the infection can progress to severe illness and death.\n\nThe theme for World Malaria Day 2024 is \"Accelerate the fight against malaria for a more equitable world.\"\n\nWorld Malaria Day is observed on April 25 across the world and an occasion to highlight the need for the prevention and control of malaria. It was established by WHO Member States at the World Health Assembly in 2007.\n\nMalaria is caused by the Plasmodium parasites that spread to humans through the bites of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes. The disease is caused by five parasitic species, P. falciparum, P. vivax, P. malariae, P. ovale and P. knowlesi. The first four are specific for humans, while P. knowlesi causes malaria in macaque monkeys.\n\nThe first symptoms usually begin within 10-15 days after the bite from a mosquito. The common symptoms include Fever, headache and chills, which may be mild and difficult to recognise. However, in malaria endemic areas, people who have developed partial immunity may not experience symptoms (asymptomatic infections).\n\nMalaria is a life-threatening disease and is not contagious and cannot spread from one person to another but is only transmitted through the bites of infected mosquitoes. There are over 400 different species of Anopheles mosquitoes and around 40, known as vector species, can transmit the disease.\n\nMalaria is a treatable disease and it can be treated through early diagnosis and correct medication. The most common medications that are used for the treatment of malaria are:", "source": {"uri": "news18.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News18"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8096175173", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "06:45:08", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T06:45:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T06:44:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.newindianexpress.com/world/2024/Apr/25/global-drive-against-malaria-slows-down-need-to-address-stark-inequities-who-2", "title": "'Global drive against malaria slows down, need to address stark inequities': WHO", "body": "Globally, four people die due to malaria every three minutes. In 2020, the Southeast Asia region was the second largest contributor of malaria cases worldwide after the African region, with around five million cases and 9000 deaths.\n\nIndia accounted for 66% of malaria cases in the WHO South-East Asia Region in 2022. The World Malaria Report said that there is an estimated 33.8 lakh cases and 5,511 deaths in India in 2022.\n\nIndia saw a decline of 30 per cent in malaria incidence and 34 per cent in mortality in 2022 compared to the previous year. India aims to eliminate malaria (zero indigenous cases) by 2030.\n\nIn 2020, 29 of the 85 malaria-endemic countries accounted for 96% of malaria cases. India contributed 1.7% of malaria cases and 1.2% of deaths globally.\n\nThe WHO SEARO head said everyone has the right to quality, timely, and affordable malaria services, yet this remains elusive for many, perpetuating a cycle of inequity that disproportionately affects the most vulnerable among us.\n\n\"Together, let us commit to accelerating the fight against malaria, forging partnerships, and implementing evidence-based strategies to achieve a more equitable world where no one is left behind in our quest to end malaria for good,\" she added.\n\nInfants and young children, especially those under five, are particularly affected, with disparities in access to education and financial resources compounding their risk.\n\nPregnant women also face heightened risks, as pregnancy reduces immunity to malaria, making them more susceptible to infection and severe disease.\n\n\"Gender inequalities, discrimination, and harmful gender norms further increase their vulnerability. Without timely and appropriate intervention, malaria in pregnancy can have devastating consequences, including severe anaemia, maternal death, stillbirth, premature delivery, and low-birth-weight babies,\" she said.\n\nRefugees, migrants, internally displaced people, and indigenous people are also at heightened risk of malaria, often excluded from disease control efforts and experiencing adverse conditions where malaria thrives, she further said.\n\nClimate change and humanitarian emergencies exacerbate these challenges, displacing populations and making them more susceptible to the disease.\n\nShe noted that there has been some progress in recent years in the Region, which witnessed a substantial decline in malaria cases and deaths, marking the most significant reduction among all WHO regions.\n\nShe said much progress has been made by countries such as Bhutan, Nepal, and Timor-Leste, demonstrating that with political commitment and collective action, malaria elimination is within reach.\n\nHowever, malaria elimination is far from over, she said.\n\nOn this occasion, WHO calls for renewed attention to the barriers to health equity, gender equality, and human rights in malaria responses.\n\n\"We must redouble our efforts to overcome these challenges and ensure that all individuals, regardless of their socio-economic status or geographical location, have access to life-saving malaria prevention, diagnosis, and treatment services,\" the regional director said.\n\n\"Moreover, by leveraging digital technology, we can better understand the diverse health needs of populations, collect and analyse data, and monitor progress in real-time, enabling us to identify and address health inequities through proven interventions and innovation in service delivery,\" she {"uri": "8096371567", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "08:54:59", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T08:54:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T08:54:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.nationalheraldindia.com/health/world-malaria-day-how-does-climate-change-impact-transmission-of-malaria", "title": "World Malaria Day: How does climate change impact transmission of malaria?", "body": "This year's theme is \"accelerating the fight against malaria for a more equitable world,\" as many people globally have no access to quality, timely treatment, and affordable services\n\nClimate plays a pivotal role in altering the transmission patterns of malaria, said experts on World Malaria Day on Thursday, 24 April.\n\nWorld Malaria Day is observed annually on 25 April, to spread awareness about the mosquito-borne disease. This year's theme is \"accelerating the fight against malaria for a more equitable world,\" as many people globally have no access to quality, timely treatment, and affordable services to prevent, detect, and treat malaria.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organization (WHO) in 2022, malaria claimed the lives of an estimated 608, 000 people worldwide and there were 249 million new cases.\n\nA 2022 Lancet study on malaria showed that an increase in temperatures could also enable the malaria parasite to develop faster and therefore escalate the transmission and burden of malaria. Even just a 2-3 degree Celsius increase could increase the population vulnerable to the disease by 5 per cent, equating to 700 million more people.\n\n\"Climate shifts play a pivotal role in altering the transmission patterns of malaria, particularly during the monsoon and pre-monsoon seasons from June to November. Fresh rainfall leads to waterlogging and the accumulation of stagnant water, creating ideal breeding grounds for the female Anopheles mosquito, the carrier of malaria parasites. This period witnessed a surge in malaria cases due to increased mosquito breeding in these water bodies,\" Dr Manish Mittal, Consultant Physician, Bhailal Amin General Hospital, Vadodara, told IANS.", {"uri": "8097166209", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "17:15:18", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T17:15:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:15:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.africa-newsroom.com/press/world-malaria-day-united-states-us-mission-uganda-strengthens-fight-against-malaria", "title": "World Malaria Day: United States (U.S) Mission Uganda Strengthens Fight against Malaria", "body": "Launched in 2005, the U.S. President's Malaria Initiative (PMI) supports implementation of malaria prevention and treatment measures as well as cross-cutting interventions\n\nToday U.S. Mission Uganda observes World Malaria Day to reaffirm our commitment to support Ugandans in the fight against malaria. Through the U.S. President's Malaria Initiative (PMI) and other collaborations, we are working closely with local partners to eliminate malaria and improve health outcomes.\n\nLaunched in 2005, the U.S. President's Malaria Initiative (PMI) supports implementation of malaria prevention and treatment measures as well as cross-cutting interventions. PMI's 2021-2026 strategy titled \"End Malaria Faster\" envisions a world free of malaria with the goal of preventing malaria cases, reducing malaria deaths and illness, and eliminating malaria in PMI partner countries.\n\nToday, Ambassador Popp attended World Malaria Day events in Namutumba District to highlight U.S. government investments in malaria prevention and response. This work is implemented by the U.S. Peace Corps and the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) through partners Holistic Initiative to Community Development (HOLD) and John Snow Inc. (JSI). Working through host organizations, Peace Corps Volunteers reach vulnerable households through evidence-based interventions.\n\nDuring his visits across Uganda, Ambassador Popp has engaged with community leaders, healthcare workers, and local residents to discuss the challenges of malaria control and explore innovative solutions. He has observed firsthand the impact of U.S.-funded initiatives, such as the distribution of insecticide-treated nets and the provision of life-saving treatments and diagnostics.\n\nMalaria remains a significant public health concern in Uganda, causing illness and death, particularly among children and pregnant women. U.S. Mission Uganda has been a key partner in providing technical and financial assistance to Uganda's malaria control efforts.\n\nThrough the U.S. President's Malaria Initiative and USAID in Uganda, we have:\n\nThese efforts have led to a significant reduction in malaria cases and deaths.\n\nU.S Mission Uganda is proud of the work we are doing with our partners to create malaria-free households where no child or pregnant woman dies because of malaria; where communities and health facilities have the medicines they need to save lives; and where there are enough trained health workers to properly diagnose and treat each Ugandan infected with malaria.\n\nThis World Malaria Day is an opportunity for us to reflect on the progress we have made together and to recommit to the actions needed to reduce malaria deaths and eliminate malaria as a public health threat.", "source": {"uri": "africa-newsroom.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Global Partnership for Education"}, "authors": {"uri": "8096056337", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "05:13:37", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T05:13:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T05:13:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/nation-world/story/2024-04-24/climate-change-is-bringing-malaria-to-new-areas-in-africa-it-never-left", "title": "Climate change is bringing malaria to new areas. In Africa, it never left", "body": "When a small number of cases of locally transmitted malaria were found in the United States last year, it was a reminder that climate change is reviving or migrating the threat of some diseases. But across the African continent malaria has never left, killing or sickening millions of people.\n\nTake Funmilayo Kotun, a 66-year-old resident of Makoko, an informal neighborhood in Nigeria's Lagos city. Its ponds of dirty water provide favorable breeding conditions for malaria-spreading mosquitoes. Kotun can't afford insecticide-treated bed nets that cost between $7 and $21 each, much less antimalarial medications or treatment.\n\nFor World Malaria Day on Thursday, here is what you need to know about the situation in Africa:\n\nThe malaria parasite mostly spreads to people via infected mosquitoes and can cause symptoms including fever, headaches and chills. It mostly affects children under 5 and pregnant women. Vaccine efforts are still in early stages: Cameroon this year became the first country to routinely give children a new malaria vaccine, which is only about 30% effective and doesn't stop transmission. A second vaccine was recently approved.\n\nCases of resistance to antimalarial drugs and insecticides are increasing, while funding by governments and donors for innovation is slowing.\n\nLiving conditions play a role, with crowded neighborhoods, stagnant water, poor sanitation and lack of access to treatment and prevention materials all issues in many areas. And an invasive species of mosquito previously seen mostly in India and the Persian Gulf is a new concern.\n\nGlobally, malaria cases are on the rise. Infections increased from 233 million in 2019 to 249 million in 85 countries in 2022. Malaria deaths rose from 576,000 in 2019 to 608,000 in 2022, according to the World Health Organization.\n\nOf the 12 countries that carry about 70% of the global burden of malaria, 11 are in Africa and the other is India. Children under 5 constituted 80% of the 580,000 malaria deaths recorded in Africa in 2022.\n\nThe fight against malaria saw some progress in areas such as rapid diagnostic tests, vaccines and new bed nets meant to counter insecticide resistance, but the COVID-19 pandemic and a shift in focus and funding set back efforts.\n\nA study published in Tropical Medicine and Infectious Disease last year said COVID-19-induced lockdowns led to disruptions at 30% of rural community health service points across Africa. Malaria cases started spiking again, breaking a downward trend between 2000 and 2019.\n\nThat downward trend could soon return, according to the WHO.\n\nAfrica is \"at the sharp end of climate change,\" and the increasing frequency of extreme weather events causes havoc in efforts to combat malaria in low- and middle-income regions, Peter Sands, the executive director of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, warned in December.\n\nIn 2023, the WHO's World Malaria Report included a chapter on the link between malaria and climate change for the first time, highlighting its significance as a potential risk multiplier. Scientists worry that people living in areas once inhospitable to mosquitoes, including the slopes of Mt. Kilimanjaro and the mountains of eastern Ethiopia, could be exposed.\n\nIn Zimbabwe, which has recorded some of its hottest days in decades, malaria transmission periods have extended in some districts, \"and this shift has been attributed to climate change,\" said Dr. Precious Andifasi, a WHO technical officer for malaria in Zimbabwe.\n\nThe Associated Press receives financial support for global health and development coverage in Africa from the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation Trust. The AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.", "source": {"uri": "sandiegouniontribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "San Diego {"uri": "8096076743", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "05:31:22", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T05:31:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T05:31:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.newsday.com/news/nation/malaria-explainer-poverty-climate-change-q96073", "title": "Climate change is bringing malaria to new areas. In Africa, it never left", "body": "LAGOS, Nigeria -- When a small number of cases of locally transmitted malaria were found in the United States last year, it was a reminder that climate change is reviving or migrating the threat of some diseases. But across the African continent malaria has never left, killing or sickening millions of people.\n\nTake Funmilayo Kotun, a 66-year-old resident of Makoko, an informal neighborhood in Nigeria's Lagos city. Its ponds of dirty water provide favorable breeding conditions for malaria-spreading mosquitoes. Kotun can't afford insecticide-treated bed nets that cost between $7 and $21 each, much less antimalarial medications or treatment.\n\nFor World Malaria Day on Thursday, here is what you need to know about the situation in Africa:\n\nMALARIA IS STILL WIDESPREAD\n\nThe malaria parasite mostly spreads to people via infected mosquitoes and can cause symptoms including fever, headaches and chills. It mostly affects children under 5 and pregnant women. Vaccine efforts are still in early stages: Cameroon this year became the first country to routinely give children a new malaria vaccine, which is only about 30% effective and doesn't stop transmission. A second vaccine was recently approved.\n\nCases of resistance to antimalarial drugs and insecticides are increasing, while funding by governments and donors for innovation is slowing.\n\nLiving conditions play a role, with crowded neighborhoods, stagnant water, poor sanitation and lack of access to treatment and prevention materials all issues in many areas. And an invasive species of mosquito previously seen mostly in India and the Persian Gulf is a new concern.\n\nA GROWING PROBLEM\n\nGlobally, malaria cases are on the rise. Infections increased from 233 million in 2019 to 249 million in 85 countries in 2022. Malaria deaths rose from 576,000 in 2019 to 608,000 in 2022, according to the World Health Organization.\n\nOf the 12 countries that carry about 70% of the global burden of malaria, 11 are in Africa and the other is India. Children under 5 constituted 80% of the 580,000 malaria deaths recorded in Africa in 2022.\n\nCOVID-19 HURT PROGRESS\n\nThe fight against malaria saw some progress in areas such as rapid diagnostic tests, vaccines and new bed nets meant to counter insecticide resistance, but the COVID-19 pandemic and a shift in focus and funding set back efforts.\n\nA study published in Tropical Medicine and Infectious Disease last year said COVID-19-induced lockdowns led to disruptions at 30% of rural community health service points across Africa. Malaria cases started spiking again, breaking a downward trend between 2000 and 2019.\n\nThat downward trend could soon return, according to the WHO.\n\nA WARMING WORLD AND NEW FRONTIERS\n\nAfrica is \"at the sharp end of climate change,\" and the increasing frequency of extreme weather events causes havoc in efforts to combat malaria in low- and middle-income regions, Peter Sands, the executive director of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, warned in December.\n\nIn 2023, the WHO's World Malaria Report included a chapter on the link between malaria and climate change for the first time, highlighting its significance as a potential risk multiplier. Scientists worry that people living in areas once inhospitable to mosquitoes, including the slopes of Mt. Kilimanjaro and the mountains of eastern Ethiopia, could be exposed.\n\nIn Zimbabwe, which has recorded some of its hottest days in decades, malaria transmission periods have extended in some districts, \"and this shift has been attributed to climate change,\" said Dr. Precious Andifasi, a WHO technical officer for malaria in Zimbabwe.", "source": {"uri": "newsday.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-04-334816063", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "07:28:36", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T07:28:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T05:10:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/climate-change-is-bringing-malaria-to-new-areas-in-africa-it-never-left/article_210f2849-360a-52e4-b4ec-cafeb6ec3908.html", "title": "Climate change is bringing malaria to new areas. In Africa, it never left", "body": "A bathroom and toilets were Funmilayo Kotun, a malaria patient and others use in Makoko neighbourhood of Lagos, Nigeria, Saturday, April 20, 2024. When cases of locally transmitted malaria were found in the United States last year, it was a reminder that climate change is reviving the threat, or broadening the range, of some diseases. But across the African continent malaria has never left.\n\nLAGOS, Nigeria (AP) -- When a small number of cases of locally transmitted malaria were found in the United States last year, it was a reminder that climate change is reviving or migrating the threat of some diseases. But across the African continent malaria has never left, killing or sickening millions of people.\n\nTake Funmilayo Kotun, a 66-year-old resident of Makoko, an informal neighborhood in Nigeria's Lagos city. Its ponds of dirty water provide favorable breeding conditions for malaria-spreading mosquitoes. Kotun can't afford insecticide-treated bed nets that cost between $7 and $21 each, much less antimalarial medications or treatment.\n\nFor World Malaria Day on Thursday, here is what you need to know about the situation in Africa:\n\nMALARIA IS STILL WIDESPREAD\n\nThe malaria parasite mostly spreads to people via infected mosquitoes and can cause symptoms including fever, headaches and chills. It mostly affects children under 5 and pregnant women. Vaccine efforts are still in early stages: Cameroon this year became the first country to routinely give children a new malaria vaccine, which is only about 30% effective and doesn't stop transmission. A second vaccine was recently approved.\n\nCases of resistance to antimalarial drugs and insecticides are increasing, while funding by governments and donors for innovation is slowing.\n\nLiving conditions play a role, with crowded neighborhoods, stagnant water, poor sanitation and lack of access to treatment and prevention materials all issues in many areas. And an invasive species of mosquito previously seen mostly in India and the Persian Gulf is a new concern.\n\nA GROWING PROBLEM\n\nGlobally, malaria cases are on the rise. Infections increased from 233 million in 2019 to 249 million in 85 countries in 2022. Malaria deaths rose from 576,000 in 2019 to 608,000 in 2022, according to the World Health Organization.\n\nOf the 12 countries that carry about 70% of the global burden of malaria, 11 are in Africa and the other is India. Children under 5 constituted 80% of the 580,000 malaria deaths recorded in Africa in 2022.\n\nCOVID-19 HURT PROGRESS\n\nThe fight against malaria saw some progress in areas such as rapid diagnostic tests, vaccines and new bed nets meant to counter insecticide resistance, but the COVID-19 pandemic and a shift in focus and funding set back efforts.\n\nA study published in Tropical Medicine and Infectious Disease last year said COVID-19-induced lockdowns led to disruptions at 30% of rural community health service points across Africa. Malaria cases started spiking again, breaking a downward trend between 2000 and 2019.\n\nThat downward trend could soon return, according to the WHO.\n\nA WARMING WORLD AND NEW FRONTIERS\n\nAfrica is \"at the sharp end of climate change,\" and the increasing frequency of extreme weather events causes havoc in efforts to combat malaria in low- and middle-income regions, Peter Sands, the executive director of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, warned in December.\n\nIn 2023, the WHO's World Malaria Report included a chapter on the link between malaria and climate change for the first time, highlighting its significance as a potential risk multiplier. Scientists worry that people living in areas once inhospitable to mosquitoes, including the slopes of Mt. Kilimanjaro and the mountains of eastern Ethiopia, could be exposed.\n\nIn Zimbabwe, which has recorded some of its hottest days in decades, malaria transmission periods have extended in some districts, \"and this shift has been attributed to climate change,\" said Dr. Precious Andifasi, a WHO technical officer for malaria in Zimbabwe.\n\nMutsaka reported from Harare, Zimbabwe.\n\nThe Associated Press receives financial support for global health and development coverage in Africa from the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation Trust. The AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley collective efforts to end malaria", "body": "Islamabad (Web Desk): President Asif Ali Zardari and Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif on Thursday called upon all partners, organizations, healthcare professionals and individuals to unite in their efforts to end malaria.\n\nIn his message on the occasion of World Malaria Day, President Zardari asked all provincial governments and other stakeholders to take joint measures to control malaria disease.\n\nThe president underscored that prevention, diagnosis and treatment of malaria was possible.\n\n\"The Government of Pakistan is committed to providing all health facilities to the people\", he said adding that Pakistan was determined to implement new initiatives under the Global Malaria Programme.\n\nPresident Zardari pointed out that the measures were aimed at testing, confirming and standardizing the treatment of every suspected case of malaria.\n\nExpressing satisfaction over the Ministry of National Health's concerted efforts to combat malaria through a joint unit, the president said the Common Management Unit Malaria adopted a comprehensive strategy.\n\n\"Unfortunately, due to the devastating floods in 2022, malaria cases had increased sharply in different parts of the country,\" President Zardari said.\n\nIn his message on the occasion, Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif emphasized collaborative efforts to strengthen healthcare systems, increase access to quality diagnosis and treatment, and raise awareness about the importance of prevention and control measures of malaria.\n\n\"The common goal of a world free of malaria can be achieved through vigorous political commitment and adequate investment mix of strategies,\" the premier said.\n\nPM Shehbaz said that the research and academic institutions need to flag scientific advances to both experts and the general public, international partners, companies and foundations to showcase their efforts and reflect on how to further scale up malaria control interventions.\n\nShehbaz Sharif said the Ministry of National Health Services and Coordination through Common Management Unit Malaria, national and international partners, provincial counterparts, NGOs and private stakeholders has significantly enhanced the free malaria testing and treatment facilities in the malaria endemic districts across the country.\n\n\"Despite the country's achievements in Malaria control, sustaining the gains still remains a challenge,\" PM Shehbaz said, adding that everyone must have access to quality assured malaria testing and treatment facilities, free of cost, at their door steps.\n\nThe World Malaria Day is observed every year on April 25 to create awareness and find solutions to the challenges being faced in controlling the disease.", {"uri": "8095985964", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "04:10:43", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T04:10:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T04:10:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://guardian.ng/features/world-malaria-day-rising-cost-of-drugs-threatens-control/", "title": "World Malaria Day: Rising cost of drugs threatens control", "body": "* Producers, pharmacies hike drugs by over 150%\n\n* Nigeria bears highest burden of malaria globally\n\nAs Nigeria joins the rest of the world to mark the 2024 World Malaria Day, the progress in national malaria control is being threatened by the continued rising cost of anti-malaria drugs, which have gone beyond the reach of many Nigerians.\n\nNigeria accounts for nearly 27 per cent of the global malaria burden globally, and the country records 55 million cases of malaria and about 90,000 malaria-related deaths yearly. Malaria is a major public health concern in Nigeria, with an estimated 68 million cases and 194,000 deaths due to the disease in 2021.\n\nThe growing deaths and cases have been linked to the escalating cost of malaria drugs. The Guardian investigation showed that the prices of most malaria drugs have increased by about 150 per cent in the last two years. For instance, Coartem Tab 80/480, which sold for N1,300 in 2022 now sells for N5,000, Lonart DS 80mg/480mg tablet is now N3,000 against N1,200 in 2022, Amatem Soft gel 80/480 is now N2,600 against N1000 it was sold in 2022, Kalther Soft gel 80/480 which was N800 in 2002 now goes for N1500.\n\nOther anti-malaria drugs prices include: Arthequick Tab N900 in 2022, now N1, 500, Lynsunate forte 80/480 N1,500 in 2022 and now sells at N2,200, Coaxin Tab N900 in 2022 now N2,100, Camosunate (Adult) N700 in 2022 and now N2,200, Camosunate (one-six years) N800 in 2022, N1,300 and Clartem DS 80/480 which was N500 in 2022, sells for N950.\n\nExperts confirmed the development and blamed the trend on the worsening economic situation in the country. According to them, the high cost of malaria treatment has pushed Nigerians to unregulated traditional medicine.\n\nA professor of Public Health Parasitology at the Nnamdi Azikiwe University, Awka, Anambra State; and Founder Malaria Eradication and Safe Health Initiative of Nigeria, Prof Dennis Aribodor told The Guardian that the rising cost of malaria drugs poses a threat to the nation's malaria control and elimination efforts, saying that a situation where malaria treatment cost over N10,000 portends danger to the fight against malaria.\n\nAribodor warned that the exorbitant cost of antimalarial medicines will worsen the already terrible situation as most Nigerians live under the poverty line. \"What this means is that Nigerians are suffering more burdens associated with malaria. There will be more morbidity and mortality, as well as recycling of poverty among the majority of the population. The economy is already biting hard on most Nigerians, and the exorbitant cost of antimalarial medicines will worsen the situation,\" he said.\n\nAribodor said with many Nigerians resorting to herbal drugs (Agbo) for the treatment of malaria and other ailments; it means that there will be more health problems in the country. \"Many Nigerians including children are already coming down with kidney and liver problems associated with consumption of unregulated herbal medicines. These problems normally end in death. The federal and state governments should declare an emergency in the treatment of malaria. Most hospital visitations are still due to malaria or consequences associated with malaria,\" he said.\n\nHe disclosed that between 2009 to around 2015, Nigeria achieved success in reducing the malaria burden through the support of global partners including UKAID- SuNMaP (Support to National Malaria Programme), World Bank Malaria Assisted Programme, United States President Malaria Initiative, other development partners and organisations.\n\nDuring that period, he said, antimalarial commodities including insecticidal-treated nets, artemisinin-based combination therapy for malaria treatment, intermittent preventive therapy for infants and pregnant women, as well as malaria diagnosis were given almost free to Nigerians.\n\nHe urged the federal and state governments to go back to that experience, to retain gains recorded in the battle against malaria. Aribodor also advocated the social marketing of antimalarial commodities.\n\n\"More importantly, political leaders should summon the political will to address the malaria burden, which has become an embarrassment to the country. If countries like Algeria where Malaria was discovered in 1808, and Cape Verde were able to eliminate malaria from their territories in 2020 and 2023, respectively, then Nigeria has no business being the malaria capital of the world. It is an unenviable record that should be reversed,\" he said.\n\nFor Aribodor, Nigeria should set a deadline for malaria elimination, which can be achieved by the year 2030, if states and Federal Governments muster the political will, mobilise needed resources including funding, human resources and give free malaria services to citizens.\n\nAlso, a pharmacist at the Heeds Pharmacy and Stores Ltd, Lugbe, Abuja, Kosamot Kayode told The Guardian that the present cost of malaria drugs is alarming and unaffordable.\n\nRafiu, who called for urgent government intervention, stated that the high cost of drugs discourages many Nigerians from seeking care in health facilities and makes them resort to traditional medicines for their healthcare needs.\n\nHe said: \"The high exchange rate is affecting the prices of drugs because most of the drugs are imported. The most affected are the anti-hypertensive and anti-diabetic drugs, especially the branded drugs. The government needs to intervene so that people will not die. The high cost of drugs has made many people to patronise Agbo, I have never seen any traditional medicine that is effective in the cure of malaria. Most of these people come to the pharmacy after trying the Agbo. If the Agbo had worked, they wouldn't come to the pharmacy.\"\n\nRafiu explained that since the Federal Government banned the use of oral artemisinin-based monotherapies (oAMTs) for malaria treatment due to recurring malaria incidents and resistance, they now use Artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) for the treatment of malaria, except for injectables.\n\n\"Currently, malaria is treated with a combination drug and the most common among them is artemether-lumefantrine because the combination enhances the curative treatment of malaria and low resistance and incidence of reoccurrence,\" he added.\n\nBut a journalist, Dele Anofi disagreed with Rafiu. He told The Guardian that he uses Agbo for the treatment of malaria because it is effective and affordable considering that the herbs can be acquired without spending on them.\n\nAnofi, however, explained that the economic situation has nothing to do with his preference for Agbo because to him, orthodox treatment of malaria is equally inexpensive. I have no fears about any negative implications of Agbo for malaria because the herbs involved have been proven not to be harmful. Besides, there's never an overdose or abuse of Agbo in malaria treatment.\n\nA traditional medicine vendor marketing Baba Aisha's product told The Guardian that with N1,200, one can get three wraps of malaria medicine, adding that the herbal mixture can be taken with pap for a complete malaria cure.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organization (WHO) 249 million new cases of malaria and 608, 000 malaria deaths were recorded globally in 2022. The global health body noted that the African Region shoulders the heaviest burden of the disease accounting for 94 per cent and 95 per cent of malaria cases and deaths.\n\nWHO added that in recent years, progress in reducing malaria has ground to a standstill, stressing that not only does malaria continue to directly endanger health and cost lives, it also perpetuates a vicious cycle of inequity.\n\nWith equity in access to malaria services as the focus of the year's World Malaria Day theme, WHO stressed the need to end discrimination and stigma, bring health care close to where people live and work through primary health care and address factors that increase malaria risk including malaria control interventions in universal health coverage.\n\n\"Not only does malaria continue to directly endanger health and cost lives, but it also perpetuates a vicious cycle of inequity. People living in the most vulnerable situations including pregnant women, infants, and children less than five years of age, refugees, migrants, internally displaced people, and indigenous peoples continue to be disproportionately impacted,\" WHO said.\n\nInfants and young children continue to suffer the greatest mortality; in 2022, an estimated 4 out of 5 malaria-related deaths in the African Region were among children under five years of age. Inequities in access to education and financial resources further exacerbate risk: children under five years of age from the poorest households in sub-Saharan Africa are five times more likely to be infected with malaria than those from the wealthiest households.", "source": {"uri": "guardian.ng", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8096227541", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "07:20:19", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T07:20:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T07:20:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.nairaland.com/8072426/accelerating-fight-against-malaria-more", "title": "\"Accelerating The Fight Against Malaria For A More Equitable World\"", "body": "In recent years, progress in eradicating Malaria has made a considerable setback. The disease continues to directly endanger human health and cost lives, not only in the most vulnerable areas, but also in countries with adequate resources.\n\nWorld Malaria Day serves as a reminder of the importance of Malaria prevention and control efforts, particularly for those living in the underdeveloped areas. The day also emphasizes the need for sustained political support and resources for Malaria control and eradication efforts.\n\nFACTS ABOUT MALARIA\n\nMalaria is a serious and sometimes fatal disease caused by plasmodium parasite that commonly infects a female anopheles mosquito which feeds on humans.\n\nPeople who get Malaria are typically very sick with symptoms like high fevers, shaking chills, and flu-like illness.\n\nThis usually appear within 10-15 days after being bitten by an infected mosquito. Some types of malaria can cause severe illness and death.\n\nSevere symptoms include: extreme tiredness and fatigue, impaired consciousness, multiple convulsions, difficulty breathing, dark or bloody urine, jaundice (yellowing of the eyes and skin) and abnormal bleeding.\n\nAlthough Malaria can be a deadly disease, illness and death from Malaria can usually be prevented.\n\nRISK GROUPS\n\nThe risk of severe infection is higher in the following groups of people: Babies, children younger than 5 years, pregnant women, travelers, and people with HIV or AIDS.\n\nMALARIA PREVENTION\n\nMalaria can be prevented by avoiding mosquito bites or taking medication.\n\n1. Vector control:\n\nWHO currently recommends either the use of insecticide-treated nets (ITNs) or indoor residual spraying (IRS) for malaria control in most malaria-prone areas.\n\n2. Prophylaxis:\n\nTravelers to malaria endemic areas should consult their physician several weeks before departure. The physician will determine which medications are appropriate for the destination country. In some cases, medication must be started 2-3 weeks before departure.\n\n3. Preventive chemotherapies:\n\nIs the use of drugs, either alone or in combination, to prevent malaria infection and its consequences. It requires the administration of a full course of an antimalarial drug to vulnerable populations at specific times during the period of greatest malaria risk, regardless of whether the recipient is infected with malaria.\n\n4. Vaccine:\n\nBeginning in October 2021, WHO recommends widespread use of the RTS,S/AS01 malaria vaccine in children living in regions with moderate to high P. falciparum malaria transmission. The vaccine has been shown to significantly reduce malaria and fatal severe malaria in young children.\n\nToday is World Malaria Day. Let's join to eliminate malaria in Africa.", "source": {"uri": "nairaland.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Nairaland"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malaria", {"uri": "2024-04-335512839", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "17:27:55", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T17:27:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:27:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://thenationonlineng.net/malaria-stakeholders-decry-nigerias-27-global-rate-contribution/", "title": "Malaria: Stakeholders decry Nigeria's 27% global rate contribution", "body": "Stakeholders within Nigeria's healthcare sector are expressing concern over the nation's significant share of the global burden, accounting for 27% of the 249 million malaria cases worldwide.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organization (WHO), in 2022, the country recorded 1.3 million cases, ranking it as the third-largest contributor globally among 85 malaria-endemic countries, meaning that urgent action is needed to enhance access to life-saving interventions in Nigeria's fight against malaria.\n\nNigeria was also responsible for 38% of global deaths in children aged under 4 years through Malaria in 2022.\n\nSpeaking in Abuja on Thursday, April 25, during this year's commemoration of World Malaria Day, WHO Representative in Nigeria, Walter Molumbo, noted that this year's theme 'Accelerating the Fight Against Malaria for a More Equitable World' resonates deeply with the ongoing efforts to combat this pervasive disease.\n\nRead Also:World Malaria Day: Firm donates insecticides products\n\nRepresented by Alex Chimbaru, WHO's Deputy Country Representative at the event organized by the Federal Ministry of Health, World Health Organization, WHO and other partners in Abuja, Mulombo said the fight against malaria is not just a health issue; it is a matter of social justice and human rights.\n\nMolumbo said: \"Over the years, malaria has disproportionately affected the most vulnerable populations, namely, pregnant women, infants, children under 5 years of age, refugees, migrants, and internally displaced people, perpetuating cycles of poverty and inequity.\n\n\"Climate change and humanitarian emergencies, including natural disasters and conflicts in malaria-endemic countries, are displacing populations, making them vulnerable to the disease.\n\n\"This reduces opportunities for accessing preventive and treatment services by these groups thus hindering progress on achieving the vision of a malaria-free world.\n\n\"However, amidst these challenges, there is cause for hope. Together, under the guidance of FMOH/NMEP, we have made remarkable strides in malaria control and prevention, thanks to the tireless dedication of individuals and organizations across the country.\n\n\"Through robust surveillance, innovative interventions, and strengthened health systems, we have saved countless lives and prevented untold suffering\".\n\nRecognizing Nigerian efforts and the need to sustain and maximize the gains, Mulombo said, \"The government's commitment to turning the tide in the fight against malaria is evident by signing the Yaound\u00e9 Declaration, in March 2024 in which the Government of Nigeria through the Honourable Minister of Health and Social Welfare pledged to accelerate efforts to reduce malaria deaths, the upcoming roundtable meeting next week is also a testimony of commitment to reduce morbidity and mortality due to malaria.\n\n\"This meeting will provide a valuable opportunity for stakeholders to explore innovative strategies and optimize our resources for a better impact. Your participation and contributions will be invaluable as we chart a course towards a malaria-free future for Nigeria.\n\n\"The fight against malaria is not just a health issue; it is a matter of social justice and human rights. By accelerating our efforts to expand access to life-saving interventions, improve health systems, and address the underlying determinants of malaria transmission, we can create a more equitable world where everyone has the opportunity to thrive. We also need to bring the communities in the planning and prevention of malaria.\n\n\"Let us change the narrative now and work together to overcome the challenges that stand in the way of malaria elimination. Through collective action, innovation, and unwavering commitment, we can achieve our shared goal of a malaria-free future for all\".\n\nIn her goodwill message, the United States government, through the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) assured of its commitment to support the country in the efforts to combat the scourge.\n\nUSAID Nigeria Deputy Director, Sara Werth, said gains of the past and ongoing efforts should be maximized for the desired results.\n\nShe said: \"In 2022, Nigeria accounted for 31% of global deaths and 38% of global deaths in children aged under 4 years. Together with our partners, the President's Malaria Initiative, PMI, helped save over 10.6 million lives and prevented 1.7 billion malaria infections worldwide since 2000.\n\n\"In Nigeria, malaria deaths decreased from 194,000 in 2021 to 188,480 in 2022. Prevention of Malaria in Nigeria has contributed to the overall global success of the PMI, program. We are proud to partner with the Nigerian government and the Global Fund to fight AIDs, Tuberculosis and malaria.\"\n\nOther stakeholders including Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation (BMGF) and Speak Up Africa, among others also assured of their continued support for the nation's Malaria eradication efforts.", "source": {"uri": "thenationonlineng.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Latest Nigeria {"uri": "8096079678", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "05:33:32", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T05:33:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T05:33:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/health/2916943-malarias-reach-extends-as-climate-change-takes-hold-but-africa-remains-endemic", "title": "Malaria's Reach Extends as Climate Change Takes Hold, but Africa Remains Endemic | Health", "body": "Kotun cant afford insecticide-treated bed nets that cost between 7 and 21 each, much less antimalarial medications or treatment.For World Malaria Day on Thursday, here is what you need to know about the situation in Africa MALARIA IS STILL WIDESPREADThe malaria parasite mostly spreads to people via infected mosquitoes and can cause symptoms including fever, headaches and chills.\n\nWhen a small number of cases of locally transmitted malaria were found in the United States last year, it was a reminder that climate change is reviving or migrating the threat of some diseases. But across the African continent malaria has never left, killing or sickening millions of people.\n\nTake Funmilayo Kotun, a 66-year-old resident of Makoko, an informal neighborhood in Nigeria's Lagos city. Its ponds of dirty water provide favorable breeding conditions for malaria-spreading mosquitoes. Kotun can't afford insecticide-treated bed nets that cost between $7 and $21 each, much less antimalarial medications or treatment.\n\nFor World Malaria Day on Thursday, here is what you need to know about the situation in Africa: The malaria parasite mostly spreads to people via infected mosquitoes and can cause symptoms including fever, headaches and chills. It mostly affects children under 5 and pregnant women. Vaccine efforts are still in early stages: Cameroon this year became the first country to routinely give children a new malaria vaccine, which is only about 30% effective and doesn't stop transmission. A second vaccine was recently approved. Cases of resistance to antimalarial drugs and insecticides are increasing, while funding by governments and donors for innovation is slowing. Living conditions play a role, with crowded neighborhoods, stagnant water, poor sanitation and lack of access to treatment and prevention materials all issues in many areas. And an invasive species of mosquito previously seen mostly in India and the Persian Gulf is a new concern. A GROWING PROBLEM Globally, malaria cases are on the rise. Infections increased from 233 million in 2019 to 249 million in 85 countries in 2022. Malaria deaths rose from 576,000 in 2019 to 608,000 in 2022, according to the World Health Organization. Of the 12 countries that carry about 70% of the global burden of malaria, 11 are in Africa and the other is India. Children under 5 constituted 80% of the 580,000 malaria deaths recorded in Africa in 2022.\n\nCOVID-19 HURT PROGRESS The fight against malaria saw some progress in areas such as rapid diagnostic tests, vaccines and new bed nets meant to counter insecticide resistance, but the COVID-19 pandemic and a shift in focus and funding set back efforts. A study published in Tropical Medicine and Infectious Disease last year said COVID-19-induced lockdowns led to disruptions at 30% of rural community health service points across Africa. Malaria cases started spiking again, breaking a downward trend between 2000 and 2019. That downward trend could soon return, according to the WHO.\n\nA WARMING WORLD AND NEW FRONTIERS Africa is \"at the sharp end of climate change,\" and the increasing frequency of extreme weather events causes havoc in efforts to combat malaria in low- and middle-income regions, Peter Sands, the executive director of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, warned in December. In 2023, the WHO's World Malaria Report included a chapter on the link between malaria and climate change for the first time, highlighting its significance as a potential risk multiplier. Scientists worry that people living in areas once inhospitable to mosquitoes, including the slopes of Mt. Kilimanjaro and the mountains of eastern Ethiopia, could be exposed. In Zimbabwe, which has recorded some of its hottest days in decades, malaria transmission periods have extended in some districts, ''and this shift has been attributed to climate change,\" said Dr. Precious Andifasi, a WHO technical officer for malaria in Zimbabwe.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": joins the rest of the world to mark this year's World Malaria Day, USAID/Nigeria mission director, Melissa Jones, said as a result of MPI procuring and distributing 90 million insecticide-treated bed nets, over 180 million Nigerians are now protected from malaria.\n\nThe mission director disclosed this on Thursday at the 2024 World Malaria Day press briefing, with the theme: 'Accelerating the Fight Against Malaria for a More Equitable World', in Abuja.\n\nShe also said that three million children under five years of age were protected from malaria after PMI assisted in administering 35 million doses of malaria preventive treatment.\n\nThe World Health Organisation (WHO) estimated that Nigeria had nearly 67 million cases in 2022, accounting for 27 per cent of the global malaria burden.\n\nAlso in 2022, Nigeria accounted for 31 per cent of global deaths and 38 per cent of global deaths in children aged under 5 years.\n\nHowever, Jones said since year 2000, in Nigeria, malaria deaths decreased from 194,000 in 2021 to 188,480 in 2022, adding that prevention of malaria in Nigeria has contributed to the overall global success of the PMI program.\n\nShe, therefore, urged the {"uri": "8096427982", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "09:27:56", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T09:27:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T09:27:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://english.jagran.com/lifestyle/insights-from-a-doctor-for-some-common-myths-and-uncovering-facts-about-malaria-10156452", "title": "Insights From A Doctor For Some Common Myths And Uncovering Facts About Malaria", "body": "The understanding of malaria is often clouded by myths and facts, shaping people's perceptions and responses to the illness. One common misconception is that malaria solely impacts individuals residing in rural areas and can spread through casual contact. In reality, malaria is a disease that can affect people regardless of their location and is transmitted exclusively through mosquito bites.\n\nAnopheles mosquitoes play a pivotal role in malaria transmission, being the only species capable of transmitting the disease. This dispels the misconception that all mosquitoes carry malaria. In a conversation with Jagran English, Dr. Susanta Kumar Ghosh, formerly with the ICMR-National Institute of Malaria Research in Bangalore and currently the Scientific Advisor at Eco BioTraps, discussed common malaria myths and facts.\n\nMalaria, a disease with a long history of impacting human health, is often surrounded by misconceptions and myths that can hinder efforts to prevent and treat it effectively. From misunderstandings about its transmission to beliefs about immunity and its seriousness, separating fact from fiction is crucial in combating this mosquito-borne illness.\n\nAs per Dr. Susanta, let's delve into some common myths about malaria and uncover the facts behind them to better understand this global health challenge. \"Accelerating the fight against malaria for a more equitable world' is the theme for World Malaria Day 2024. This emphasizes the need for comprehensive engagement of individuals, communities, governments, and civil society for the ultimate endgame for malaria.\n\n1. Myth: Malaria Is Only A Problem In Tropical Regions\n\nFact: While malaria is more prevalent in tropical and subtropical regions, it can also occur in temperate climates. Cases have been reported in places like Europe and North America, although they are less common and often related to travel and migration.\n\n2. Myth: Malaria Is Caused By Being Near Standing Water\n\nFact: While mosquitoes that carry malaria parasites often breed in standing water, simply being near water does not cause malaria. It's the bite of an infected mosquito that transmits the malaria parasite (Plasmodium) to humans.\n\nAlso Read: 6 Key Reasons To Add Yogurt To Your Diet For Clean Skin And Healthy Hair\n\n3. Myth: Malaria Is Caused By A Virus\n\nFact: Malaria is not caused by a virus but by a parasite. The Plasmodium parasite is transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected Anopheles mosquito. There are several species of Plasmodium, with P. falciparum and P. vivax being the most common and dangerous if not diagnosed and treated in time.\n\nFact: Malaria cannot be treated with antibiotics because it's a parasitic infection, not a bacterial one. Instead, antimalarial drugs such as chloroquine, artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs), and others are used for treatment, depending on the type and drug resistance patterns.\n\n5. Myth: Malaria Only Affects Humans\n\nFact: While humans are the primary hosts for the malaria parasite, it can infect other animals as well. However, these infections typically do not contribute significantly to the spread of malaria among humans. The fifth human malaria parasite, Plasmodium knowlesi, is basically malaria in monkeys, prevalent in some regions of Southeast Asia, mainly Malaysia.\n\n6. Myth: Once You've Had Malaria, You're Immune For Life\n\nFact: Having malaria once does not guarantee lifelong immunity. Immunity can develop after repeated infections, but it's not absolute and can wane over time, especially if a person moves away from malaria-endemic areas.\n\n7. Myth: All Mosquitoes Transmit Malaria\n\nFact: Only female Anopheles mosquitoes of certain species can transmit malaria. Not all mosquitoes carry the Plasmodium parasite, and even among Anopheles species, not all are vectors for malaria.\n\n8. Myth: Malaria Is Not A Serious Disease\n\nFact: Malaria can be a life-threatening disease, especially if caused by P. falciparum, which can lead to severe complications such as cerebral malaria, multiorgan dysfunction, and death if not treated promptly and effectively.\n\n9. Myth: Malaria Is No Longer A Problem Because Of Modern Medicine\n\nFact: While progress has been made in malaria control and prevention, it still poses a significant health threat in many parts of the world, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa. Factors like drug resistance, insecticide resistance, lack of access to healthcare, and environmental changes contribute to its persistence.\n\nAlso Read: What Is PGAD, Medical Condition That Left US Woman With Permanent Arousal?\n\n10. Myth: Mosquito Nets Are The Only Effective Way To Prevent Malaria\n\nFact: Mosquito nets, such as long-lasting insecticide-treated nets (LLINs), can prevent mosquito bites and thus malaria transmission, but only on a short-term basis. Long-term elimination strategies based on science, like the use of eco-friendly ovitraps as source reduction and biological control agents, play a crucial role in malaria prevention.\n\nAt last, Dr. Susanta said, Understanding these myths and facts is important for raising awareness about malaria and promoting effective prevention and treatment strategies.", "source": {"uri":
