The programme was organised by the State Health and Family Welfare Society, putting light on the importance of early diagnosis, treatment, and preventive measures.\n\nAlso Read | Earthquake in Haryana: Mild Quake of 3.2 Magnitude on Richter Scale Jolts Sirsa.\n\nAddressing the gathering, Governor Nallu emphasised the pivotal role of collective action in eradicating malaria. He stressed the need for sustained efforts from all stakeholders, including government agencies, healthcare professionals, civil society organisations, and the public, to achieve the goal of a malaria-free Tripura.\n\nFurthermore, Governor Nallu highlighted the state government's robust measures to curb malaria transmission, including the distribution of insecticide-treated bed nets, indoor residual spraying, and intensified surveillance and monitoring systems. He reiterated the government's unwavering commitment to ensuring accessible and affordable healthcare services to every citizen, particularly those in remote and vulnerable communities.\n\nAlso Read | Surat Lok Sabha Election 2024: Wanted Posters for Missing Congress Leader Nilesh Kumbhani Surface on Hirabaug Bridge of Gujarat Amid Rumours of Likely Defection to BJP (Watch Video).\n\nThe event also witnessed the participation of healthcare experts, researchers, and representatives from non-governmental organisations, fostering dialogue and collaboration towards innovative strategies for malaria control and elimination.\n\nIn his closing remarks, Governor Nallu called for renewed dedication and solidarity in the fight against malaria, urging individuals to adopt preventive practices such as proper sanitation, use of mosquito repellents, and timely medical intervention.\n\nNotably, World Malaria Day, observed annually on April 25, serves as a global platform to raise awareness and mobilise support for malaria prevention and control initiatives.\n\nNallu said, \"The Indian government has taken the initiative to eradicate Malaria from all states of our country. In Tripura, the government has set a target of 2027 to completely eradicate Malaria from Tripura. I would like to make all the people of Tripura aware, that the places where there are chances of mosquito breeding, the places must be neat and cleaned properly.\"\n\n\"We must keep noticing such places where there is stored water because of which mosquitoes are breeding,\"\n\n\"People can inform the government and get help in mosquito eradication. Those who are already suffering from malaria must take proper medicine and take precautions till the complete eradication of Malaria takes place,\" he concluded. {"uri": "8096138223", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "06:19:36", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T06:19:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T06:18:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://foreignaffairs.co.nz/2024/04/25/mil-osi-australia-eliminating-malaria-in-our-region/", "title": "MIL-OSI Australia: Eliminating malaria in our region", "body": "Source: Australian Government - Minister of Foreign Affairs\n\nAustralia is investing up to $30 million to support governments and communities across the Pacific and Southeast Asia deliver new tools and build critical skills to eliminate malaria.\n\nMalaria remains a major challenge in our region with over 7 million reported cases in 2022, and rising infection rates in some countries. Malaria is a burden on families and health systems, slowing development and restricting growth.\n\nNew tools are urgently needed to address the emerging resistance to current treatments, and the impact of climate change, which threaten to roll back progress achieved against malaria.\n\nOur new package, announced on World Malaria Day, provides comprehensive support ranging from preventing infections through strengthened mosquito control to developing better testing tools and improved treatments.\n\nThis includes $5 million to James Cook University to support Pacific countries to strengthen surveillance and control of mosquito-borne diseases like malaria, dengue and zika.\n\nIt also includes a new $8 million partnership with non-government health organisation PATH, in a consortium with Australia's Burnet Institute and the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research, to develop new diagnostic tests targeted to our region.\n\nAdditionally, we are partnering with the Medicines for Malaria Venture, providing $17 million for the development of new malaria treatments including medicines suitable for use in pregnancy and for children.\n\nThis new package is part of the Partnerships for a Healthy Region initiative, which works with governments and civil society organisations in the Pacific and Southeast Asia to build resilient, equitable and inclusive health systems.\n\nIt adds to our existing support for malaria elimination, including through the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, the Asia Pacific Leaders Malaria Alliance, and the Innovative Vector Control Consortium.\n\nQuotes attributable to Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator the Hon Penny Wong:\n\n\"Malaria is not only a threat to the health and wellbeing of communities in the Pacific and Southeast Asia, it also impacts education, tourism and economic growth.\n\n\"Investing in our partnerships with our region and its capacity to test and treat malaria is clearly in Australia's interest.\"\n\nQuotes attributable to Minister for International Development and the Pacific, the Hon Pat Conroy MP:", "source": {"uri": "foreignaffairs.co.nz", "dataType": {"uri": "8097056363", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "15:57:43", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T15:57:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T15:56:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://tribuneonlineng.com/effective-hygienic-practice-key-to-ending-malaria-scourge-ekiti-govt/", "title": "Effective hygienic practice key to ending malaria scourge  --  Ekiti govt", "body": "Ekiti state government has called on the citizens to support the efforts of the administration at stamping out the spread of malaria disease in the state with proper hygienic practice.\n\nThe commissioner for health and human services, Dr Oyebanji Filani spoke on Thursday during an event organized in commemoration of this year's World Malaria Day under the Immunization Plus and Malaria Progress by Accelerating Coverage and Transforming Services(IMPACT project) being implemented by the Solina Health.\n\nThe commissioner who was represented by the Permanent Secretary in the ministry, Mrs Olusola Gbenga-Igotun, explained that there is a need for the people, especially nursing and pregnant mothers to maintain good hygienic behaviour to ward off mosquitoes, which spread the disease.\n\nHe added that poor hygiene by the people has been identified as one of the fastest ways of spreading malaria disease, noting that the residents should do more by taking care of their environment with proper waste disposal.\n\nFilani said that the administration of Biodun Oyebanji in almost two years has initiated policies towards providing quality healthcare for the people, including anti-malaria drugs and insecticide-treated nets.\n\nHe said, \"When you want to get a malaria-free society, it is better to start with the pregnant women and other nursing women, hence the need we gathered here.\n\n\"We believe that if our women could be properly sensitised, they will serve as our advocate to the rest of the people. We need to have a clean environment for us to have a malaria-free society. It is not enough that you sleep under the net, it is also very essential for a clean and safe environment, devoid of where mosquitoes can breathe.\"\n\nOn the government's efforts at tackling the malaria scourge, the permanent secretary said, \"The government has been doing well in this regard and we are privileged to be under the Impact malaria project which has helped us in advocacy and distribution of treated nets and drugs to the people.\n\n\"We are winning the battle and with the support of our women, I know we will definitely win.\"\n\nSpeaking, the Project Director of Solina Health, Dr Ayodele Alegbeleye explained that in the last few months, the organization in collaboration with the government has carried out full-scale implementation of malaria interventions across 201 primary healthcare facilities in the state.\n\nHe revealed that over 700 staff in the facilities have also been trained including other basic and technical services aimed at addressing the scourge of malaria especially among pregnant and nursing mothers.\n\nThe state coordinator of the Word Health Organisation (WHO) Akeem Busari represented by Dr Isaac Adedayo said that \"malaria vaccines are a {"uri": "8096523165", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "10:22:10", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T10:22:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T10:21:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://healthwise.punchng.com/rising-antimalarial-drug-costs-deepen-patients-plight-in-six-months/", "title": "Rising antimalarial drug costs deepen patients' plight in six months - Healthwise", "body": "Angela Onwuzoo As the world marks this year's World Immunisation Week, the United Nations Children's Fund has said vaccines have...\n\nAs Nigeria join the rest of the world to commemorate World Malaria Day today, patients have lamented the rising prices of antimalarial medications amidst fears of financial instability and reduced life expectancy.\n\nThough the Federal Government said it is taking steps for intervention, Nigerians still grapple with the rising cost of drugs, including antimalarial drugs.\n\nWMD is commemorated every year on April 25 and recognises global efforts to control malaria. This year's celebration is themed, 'Accelerating the fight against malaria for a more equitable world,' according to the World Health Organisation.\n\nFindings by our correspondent showed that the prices of some antimalarial drugs have increased from 12 per cent to 23 per cent from November 2023 to April 2024.\n\nIn November, an Artesunate injection of 120mg was sold for N2,500, while the 60mg of the injection was sold for N1,800.\n\nCoartem 80/480 was N3, 300, while Amatem soft gel was sold for N2,500, and Lonart 80/480mg, for N2,850.\n\nHowever, in April, market surveys showed that Artesunate 120mg now sells for N2,800, while 60mg of the injection now sells for N2,000. Coartem 80/480 is now sold for N4,000. Amatem soft gel, N3, 000; and Lonart 80/480mg for N3, 500.\n\nA school teacher, Amina Yusuf lamented that the hike in antimalarial drugs has become unbearable and there is a need for the government to urgently intervene.\n\n\"They keep telling us that we should not use concoctions to treat ourselves, yet we can't afford the drugs at the pharmacies.\n\n\"Malaria is common in Nigeria, hence the need for the government to intervene. The high prices of drugs have become unbearable, and my take-home pay at the end of the month is not enough,\" Yusuf said.\n\nMr Akin Ojo said he resorted to taking herbal medicines when he was diagnosed with malaria because he could not afford antimalarial drugs at the pharmacy.\n\n\"When taking those medications, you have to eat well. They will still tell you to buy paradol or paracetamol, and by the time you calculate everything, you will see that people like us can't afford it,\" he lamented.\n\nIn 2023, the former Minister of Health, Dr Osagie Ehanire said an estimated 55 million cases of malaria and nearly 90,000 malaria deaths occur each year in Nigeria.\n\nHe noted that the economic burden of malaria in Nigeria was estimated at $1.6b (N687bn) in 2022 and may increase to about $2.8bn (N2tn) in 2030.\n\nSpeaking with our correspondent, the National Chairman of the Association of Community Pharmacists in Nigeria, Adewale Oladigbolu, said the government needs to invest adequately in the health sector to reduce the prices of drugs in the country.\n\n\"Patients are not meant to have a problem with the prices of drugs if the health insurance is working in Nigeria. The government needs to invest so we can make Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients because many of the antimalarial drugs are imported.\n\n\"For those that are locally made, they have to improve the APIs, and they are subject to changes in exchange rates.\n\n\"If the government invests in the sector and partners with the private sector, that will help in the reduction of antimalarial drugs. Nigeria is probably the country that has the highest antimalarial consumption rate in the whole world,\" he said.\n\nThe African Region carries a high proportion of the global malaria burden, accounting for about 95 per cent of all malaria cases and 96 per cent of all malaria deaths in 2021, according to WHO.\n\nWHO Regional Director for Africa, Dr Matshidiso Moeti said, \"While Nigeria accounts for around 27 per cent of the global burden of malaria cases, the country has seen major progress.\n\n\"Malaria incidence has fallen by 26 per cent since 2000, from 413 per 1000 to 302 per 1000 in 2021. Malaria deaths also fell by 55 per cent, from 2.1 per 1000 population to 0.9 per 1000 population.\n\n\"Drivers of this continuing disease burden include the size of Nigeria's population, making scaling up intervention challenging; suboptimal surveillance systems, which pick up less than 40 per cent of the country's malaria data; inadequate funding to ensure universal interventions across all states; and health-seeking behaviour, where people use the private sector, with limited regulation, preferentially.\"\n\nMeanwhile, WHO said malaria remains a serious global health challenge that takes its heaviest toll on the most vulnerable.\n\nIt stated that young children living in the poorest households in sub-Saharan Africa are disproportionately affected by the disease.\n\n\"Pregnant women, refugees, migrants, internally displaced people, and Indigenous Peoples are among the other groups at higher risk of contracting malaria.\n\n\"Too many people continue to miss out on the services and information they need to prevent, detect and treat malaria, especially those experiencing disadvantage, discrimination and exclusion,\" it said.\n\nThe WHO noted that there is a need to strengthen and step up support for these populations, stressing that it is the best way to get back on track to achieve the global malaria targets.", "source": {"uri": "healthwise.punchng.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Healthwise"}, "authors": [{"uri": "lara_adejoro@healthwise.punchng.com", "name": "Lara Adejoro", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antimalarial_medication", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Antimalarial medication"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malaria", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Malaria"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nigeria", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Nigeria"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Nigeria"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artemether/lumefantrine", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "lumefantrine"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Malaria_Day", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "World Malaria Day"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immunization", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Immunization"}}, {"uri": "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.thestar.com.my/news/world/2024/04/26/somalia-cuts-malaria-prevalence-to-4-pct-in-2023-despite-new-strains-who", "title": "Somalia cuts malaria prevalence to 4 pct in 2023, despite new strains: WHO", "body": "MOGADISHU, April 25 (Xinhua) -- Somalia has made tangible progress to tackle malaria by reducing the prevalence rate to 4.1 percent in 2023 from 20.1 percent in 2015, the World Health Organization (WHO) said Thursday.\n\nThe UN health agency said the gain was made in the most affected areas by adopting an integrated disease response with support from the WHO and the UN Children's Fund (UNICEF) and donors.\n\nSomalia's malaria program reduced disease incidence to as low as 3.4 percent in 2022 by applying prevention, interruption and supplementary measures, as documented by the country's National Malaria Control Program.\n\nHowever, the effects of the nation's drought and floods contributed to a minor increase in incidence in 2023, to 4 percent, according to the WHO.\n\n\"Detection of new malaria strains, compounded by persistent insecurity and health impacts of climate change, may exacerbate the malaria situation in the country,\" Jamal Amran, WHO Somalia's focal person for malaria control, said in a statement issued in Mogadishu, the capital of Somalia.\n\nA historic drought affected Somalia from 2022 to 2023, and the country has since been hit by heavy rainfalls due to the El Nino phenomenon, according to the WHO.\n\nSuch rapid changes to climate, including temperature, rainfall patterns and humidity, could easily lead to further geographic expansion of malaria transmission or new variation, it said.\n\nDuring 2023, Somalia increasingly detected a new strain of the parasite Plasmodium falciparum, which is hard to detect with the usual rapid diagnostic test, as well as a new urban invasive vector for malaria, the mosquito Anopheles stephensi, in several districts, the WHO said.\n\nThe country also has a large number of people on the move, including nomadic communities, internally displaced people, and people arriving from neighboring countries Djibouti, Ethiopia, Kenya and Yemen.\n\n\"This tends to increase the disease prevalence, including malaria, owing to contributing factors such as overcrowded environments, limited access to health care, and lack of awareness,\" the WHO said.", 0.04313725490196085, "wgt": 152, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8096674597", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "11:56:12", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T11:56:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T11:55:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/science-and-disease/malaria-super-mosquitoes-stealth-parasites-drug-resistance/", "title": "Why the fight against malaria is having a 'Red Queen' moment", "body": "Scientists working to eradicate malaria face three threats to progression: stealth parasites, super mosquitoes and mounting resistance\n\nAs Alice and the Red Queen run towards a chessboard in Lewis Carroll's childhood classic, the wind whistling in their ears, the little girl makes a curious discovery: despite running very fast for a very long time, she hasn't actually moved.\n\nThe Red Queen appears unfazed. \"Here, you see, it takes all the running you can do, to keep in the same place,\" she explains. \"If you want to get somewhere else, you must run twice as fast as that.\"\n\nFor malaria researchers and practitioners, this sensation feels all too familiar. Despite several exciting advances, efforts to tackle the parasitic pathogen have stalled since 2015: then, according to the World Health Organization (WHO), 586,000 people died from the disease; in 2022, it killed 608,000.\n\n\"It really does seem like a Red Queen scenario, we do an awful lot of running [to] make small steps forward,\" says Prof Chris Drakeley, a professor of infection and immunity at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine.\n\nThat's because both the malaria parasite and the mosquitoes which spread it are wily opponents, constantly evolving to evade efforts to wipe out the disease. \"Any organism, when you put pressure on it, will change,\" Prof Drakeley says. \"I think the challenge at the moment is really: how do we deal with these changes?\"\n\nThree biological threats are of particular concern to experts grappling to eradicate malaria: stealth parasites, super mosquitoes, and mounting resistance.\n\n\"Right now we are in this sort of turning point moment, where it could go either way,\" says Prof Olivo Miotto, a malaria genomics expert at the Mahidol-Oxford Tropical Medicine Research Unit in Bangkok.\n\nStealth parasites\n\nThe first issue affects diagnostics. In 2010, researchers in the Peruvian Amazon detected an unusual mutation: some parasites no longer had HRP2 proteins, which many lateral flow tests use to detect malaria. This meant cases could be missed, giving the disease - and the genetic quirk - space to circulate.\n\nSince then, the deletion has spread across continents. While prevalence estimates vary, a concerning hotspot has emerged in the Horn of Africa - some studies have suggested as many as 80 per cent of asymptomatic cases in Djibouti and Eritrea have could not be picked up by rapid diagnostics reliant on the HRP2 and HRP2 protein. In 2022, according to the WHO, 415.5 million such tests were sold worldwide.\n\n\"There's a different antigen [test] to pick this up, but it's not as well researched and developed,\" says Dr Stephen Woolley, an honorary clinical researcher and malaria specialist at the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine. \"WHO is trying to validate these newer tests... but I think this could be a really big challenge to global health and malaria control.\n\n\"We're seeing that in the Horn of Africa, and it's now spreading to Kenya and Uganda,\" he says, adding that doctors have also identified the issue in clinics in Britain. Earlier this week, the UK Health Security Agency said the number of malaria cases diagnosed here among travellers exceeded 2,000 for the first time since 2001.\n\nBut the deletion does not mean the malaria parasite is \"under an invisibility cloak\", says Prof Drakeley, as cases can still be diagnosed in the laboratory. He is optimistic that the issue - which affects only a tiny proportion of global malaria infections - can be contained, and that newer rapid diagnostics to solve it are on the horizon.\n\nSuper mosquitoes\n\nSuper mosquitoes have also emerged and appear to be driving an unexpected surge in malaria across the Horn of Africa. Combined with the changing parasite, the impact could be terrible.\n\n\"The genotype of the parasite, mixed with Anopheles stephensi [mosquito]... is a recipe for disaster potentially in Africa, and could make elimination extremely difficult,\" says Dr Woolley.\n\nUnlike the Anopheles gambiae mosquito, the most widespread carrier of malaria, the highly adaptable Anopheles stephensi thrives in urban areas and breeds almost anywhere - in a dirty puddle between slum shacks, a rubbish dump, or even water in an abandoned car tyre.\n\nIt also survives in high temperatures in dry seasons, when malaria transmission usually lulls.\n\nNative to parts of Asia and the Arabian peninsula, its arrival in Africa has triggered concerns that the burden of disease could shift from rural to urban areas. It was first spotted in Djibouti in 2012, and was a key driver of a 2,800 per cent surge over the next eight years.\n\nIt has since spread to countries including Ethiopia, Somalia and Nigeria, while the WHO has described it as a \"threat to malaria control and elimination\", especially in African megacities.\n\n\"There's clearly a concern around the arrival of the anopheles stephensi in Africa and the impact of that is still, in my view, extremely uncertain,\" says Prof Nick White, a professor at the Mahidol-Oxford Tropical Medicine Research Unit, who specialises in malaria.\n\n\"It's a worry because we have an increasing change in the demography in Africa, with a move from rural areas to cities. It follows that a city-dwelling mosquito would do quite well - but it's not a fantastic vector.\"\n\nBut with the stephensi, \"it feels like for once we are above the curve\", says Dr Jackie Cook, co-director of the Malaria Centre at the LSHTM. The vector was detected early, surveillance networks have been established, and vector control efforts are ramping up.\n\nResistance\n\nThe same cannot be said for drug and insecticide resistance, which have repeatedly emerged.\n\n\"We're a little bit slow at having new things coming through the pipeline, we never seem to be ahead of the curve,\" she warns. \"We're always waiting for something bad to happen, and then we react to it.\"\n\nThere are two forms of resistance: resistance among mosquitoes to insecticides, and resistance among parasites to antimalarial drugs.\n\nIn the WHO's latest malaria report, published in November, the agency warned that 87 per cent of countries have reported some resistance to pyrethroid-based insecticides, 82 per cent to organochlorines, 69 per cent of carbamates, and 60 per cent to organophosphates.\n\nThis problem has not emerged overnight - reduced efficacy of pyrethroid, which is used on bednets, was first noticed more than a decade ago. While there have been efforts to rotate or mix insecticides, it was not until last year that the WHO updated its recommendations to also use chlorfenapyr - the first insecticide in some 40 years, which grounds mosquitoes by causing their wings to spasm.\n\nThis has proven to be incredibly effective: a study earlier this month found that the rollout of the potent insecticide has prevented at least 13 million cases in Africa.\n\nDr Cook says the new insecticide coated bednets are \"fantastic\", but is concerned they will lull us into a false sense of security.\n\n\"It feels like we're all piling on chlorfenapyr - lots of companies are pivoting because it's been shown to be more effective, which creates more competition and brings prices down. But what's next? Will we find ourselves in the same situation 10 years down the line? There doesn't seem to be much else coming through the pipeline.\n\n\"We're spending all this money monitoring the situation, but we should have put a lot of that money into developing the new tools,\" Dr Cook adds. \"I think we've done things badly in terms of insecticide resistance. The concern is we do the same with drug resistance as well.\"\n\nThis would be a major blow. At the moment, doctors are predominantly reliant on artemisinin-based treatments to tackle malaria - between 2010 and 2022, more than four billion courses were delivered to clinics by manufacturers.\n\nCurrently, the WHO describes the status as \"partial resistance\" - drugs still work, just more slowly. But the issue is spreading, having jumped from the Greater Mekong Region where it was first noted, to Africa.\n\n\"We rely entirely on artemisinin combination treatments, of which there are over half a billion treatments given each year,\" says Prof White. \"If we lose these, we're in serious trouble - because despite all the large investments in antimalarial drug discovery in the past 20 years, we've been rather unsuccessful.\n\n\"There are new drugs that could save us - candidates from Novartis look most promising - but they are still three to five years away,\" he says.\n\nHe adds that efforts are underway to reduce the rise of resistance - such as using two other drugs alongside artemisinin, not just one, and encouraging people to finish their course. But this is likely only \"sticking a plaster\" on the issue - at some point, full resistance will spread.\n\nSlither of light - and age-old issues\n\nOf course, it's not all doom and gloom, and there have been huge steps forward in efforts to eradicate malaria.\n\nMost significant is the rollout of two new malaria vaccines: in July 2022 GSK's RTS,S shot, also known as Mosquirix, was approved, followed by Oxford University's R21 immunisation in December. Experts say these shots, which are around 75 per cent effective at preventing the disease in areas where transmission is seasonal, could save tens of thousands of children's lives every year.\n\n\"The vaccine is the latest 'shiny thing' for humans, but alone it's not going to end malaria transmission,\" says Prof Drakeley. \"But it will save lives... it's a nine per cent reduction in all cause mortality in children, that's massively impressive.\"\n\nOther exciting tools - from gene drive mosquitoes to spatial repellents for homes and buildings - are also emerging, with researchers describing it as an \"exciting time\" to be in the malaria field.\n\nCountries are also containing the disease: in 2023, Azerbaijan, Belize and Tajikistan all eliminated the parasitic pathogen, joining 40 other countries certified as malaria-free, while regions like southeast Asia - where the disease once thrived - now have minimal infections.\n\nYet there are concerns that the funding needed to replicate these successes is dwindling - according to analysis from Malaria No More and the Oxford Economics Group, the proportion of global research and development funding dedicated to malaria has fallen from $707m in 2019 to $604m in 2022.\n\n\"Governments, research institutions and funding organisations must keep their foot on the accelerator to continue fostering novel interventions and treatments to maintain a robust malaria pipeline for the future,\" says Gareth Jenkins, an executive director at Malaria No More UK. \"If we don't, this disease can thrive again.\"\n\nThere are other \"not very politically digestible\" issues too, says Prof White, \"such as incompetence, corruption, fabrication of data, wrong results - all those sorts of things that no one ever talks about, but are actually quite important\".\n\nAnd then there are the broader societal issues - including climate change, extreme weather events, conflict and mass migration - that could derail eradication efforts, providing opportunities for malaria to thrive and new obstacles to deliver services.\n\n\"The playground for this disease is basically social circumstances - it's poverty, lack of resources, lack of accessibility to the really basic health services,\" says Prof Miotto. \"And in that sense, the failure of rapid tests or partial artemisinin resistance makes little difference if you don't have any rapid tests, and you don't have any drugs. We can't lose sight of the basics.\"\n\nProtect yourself and your family by learning more about Global Health Security", "source": {"uri": "telegraph.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Telegraph"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sarah_newey@telegraph.co.uk", "name": "Sarah Newey", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horn_of_Africa", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Horn of Africa"}, "location": null}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malaria", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Malaria"}}, {"uri": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9507943", "eventUri": "eng-9507943", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.05098039215686279, "wgt": 151, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8097206345", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "17:47:47", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T17:47:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:46:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.khmertimeskh.com/501478468/yeang-chheang-cambodias-unsung-hero-in-fight-against-malaria/", "title": "Yeang Chheang - Cambodia's unsung hero in fight against malaria - Khmer Times", "body": "Click here to get Khmer Times Breaking News direct into your Telegram\n\nYeang Chheang may not be a name many people recognise, but in the field of malaria control this 86-year-old Cambodian is a legend.\n\nIn 1954, at age 17, Chheang began training as a medical entomologist - his country's first. During the deadly Khmer Rouge regime in the mid-1970s, he saved countless lives by dispensing malaria medication from his pockets. In the decades after the war, he helped rebuild the country's shattered malaria control programme from scratch.\n\nToday, as Cambodia approaches malaria elimination, Chheang is finally getting the recognition he deserves: In December, he received the \"Unsung Hero\" award at the United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP28) in Dubai for the sacrifices he made in efforts to eliminate this deadly infectious disease.\n\n\"A life of unwavering service to preventing illness and saving lives is an exceptional career worthy of recognition in and of itself,\" Dr David Walton, the US Global Malaria Coordinator at the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), wrote in a recent letter to Chheang. \"To do so through the terror and suffering of the Khmer Rouge regime and to rebuild in its wake is truly heroic.\"\n\nChheang, a soft-spoken man with wire-rimmed glasses and a razor-sharp memory, has remained humble through it all. One recent muggy afternoon while sipping coconut water in his Phnom Penh apartment, the retired entomologist quietly recounted the horrors and blessings of the seven decades he spent on the front lines of the war on malaria.\n\nCambodia's Historic Milestone\n\nFor decades, malaria has ranked as one of the most common causes of illness and death in Cambodia, where many of the country's 17 million residents live and work in rural villages surrounded by dense forests that also are home to malaria-carrying mosquitoes.\n\nBut recently, Cambodia has reached an incredible milestone: Not a single malaria death has been recorded in more than six years, and the total number of infection cases in 2023 decreased by two-thirds from the previous year. Suddenly, the dream of eliminating malaria in Cambodia is a real possibility.\n\nNo one person or programme can take full credit for the turnaround; but together, the Cambodian government; the US President's Malaria Initiative (PMI), led by USAID and co-implemented with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention; and the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria have accomplished a great deal. Chheang helped lead control efforts from the very beginning.\n\nChheang was born in a rural commune in Kampong Thom Province, where he lived with his parents and four siblings, all of whom would later die in the Khmer Rouge genocide. From a young age, Chheang had a fascination with insects. But it wasn't until age 17, when a French entomologist at the Institut de Biologie took him under his wing and trained him in vector control, that he decided on his future career path.\n\n\"I was fascinated with insects, especially the mosquito which could deliver this powerful disease from its bite,\" Chheang said through an interpreter. \"I am forever grateful to (him) for recognising my interest and training me.\"\n\nIn 1960, during the rule of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Chheang was sent to study in the Philippines. When he returned to Cambodia, he became a 23-year-old entomologist technician at the Ministry of Health's national malaria control programme. He helped initiate the first malaria eradication pilot project in Kratie province in the 1960s and held a number of senior roles in the malaria programme technical bureau when the Khmer Rouge seized power in 1975.\n\nSacrifice and Courage\n\nLike most Cambodians at the time, Chheang experienced horrific loss and sacrifice under the Khmer Rouge. His three brothers, sister, and mother were murdered. His wife and their 10-month-old son starved to death in a labour camp. Chheang was evacuated by foot to Preah Net Preah district in Banteay Meanchey province, but before leaving Phnom Penh he secretly stashed packets of antimalarial pills in his pockets.\n\nAt first Chheang tried to keep his pharmacy a secret, fearing retribution from the Khmer Rouge soldiers. But as more prisoners were cured of malaria, the soldiers took notice and demanded treatment for themselves.\n\nThen one day, a top regional military leader became sick and sent for Chheang.\n\n\"I was so scared and thought if anything went wrong, I would be killed right there in front of everyone,\" he said. Instead, the commander was cured and Chheang gained the respect of fellow prisoners and his captors alike. \"After this, they allowed me to move freely from home to home to treat sick people. Anyone with a fever was referred to me.\"\n\nWhile Chheang worked to save lives, Pol Pot's Khmer Rouge killed an estimated two million people from 1975 to 1979, including many doctors and other health professionals. Chheang also lost the majority of his colleagues from the malaria control programme.\n\n\"I survived the Khmer Rouge because of those malaria tablets. They were my blessing,\" he says.\n\nRebuilding\n\nAfter the war, Chheang was one of just five malaria workers remaining who returned to Phnom Penh to help restore the national malaria control programme - with no budget or staff - from ground zero. He also picked up other pieces of his life and married his late wife's younger sister, Nong Bunny, who was then a lab technician in the malaria programme.\n\nOne of his biggest accomplishments at the time, Chheang says, was organising training for 68 participants from 24 provinces to be able to test and treat malaria. Cambodia lacked healthcare providers, medical equipment and supplies, but Chheang convinced the World Health Organization (WHO) in Manila to provide tests, slides, microscopes, and drugs through UNICEF to help the national programme get its start.\n\nPartnering with PMI\n\nChheang spent many years working alongside USAID-supported PMI projects, including the Malaria Control in Cambodia, or MCC, project in western Cambodia. He would often travel to Pailin province near the Thailand border - a former Khmer Rouge stronghold and well-known epicentre of drug resistance and high-burden malaria cases. In Pailin, he led his team on foot for days or weeks through villages riddled with land mines. They took on grave personal risk to identify mosquitoes and their breeding sites, and to deliver treated nets to villagers living there.\n\nHe would also frequently encounter former Khmer Rouge fighters in the area who had surrendered to government forces and were granted amnesty. Chheang says he treated everyone needing help with the same compassion and respect, regardless of their past. \"If we don't help people with malaria, we cease to be humans.\"\n\nAn Inspiration to the Malaria Community\n\nChheang retired in 2016, but his contributions to the elimination of malaria and his work with the National Center for Parasitology, Entomology and Malaria Control won't soon be forgotten. Cambodia would not be where it is today without the hard work and dedication of disease control pioneers like Yeang Chheang.\n\n\"Your success is an inspiration to me, my colleagues at the US President's Malaria Initiative, and all of the malaria community,\" Dr Walton wrote in his letter to Yeang Chheang. \"It is my greatest hope that we can achieve a world free of malaria through the same hard work, dedication, and perseverance.\"", "source": {"uri": "khmertimeskh.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Khmer Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8096879873", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "14:01:13", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T14:01:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T14:00:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.jagrantv.com/en-show/world-malaria-day-know-viral-fever-in-children-symptoms-prevention-tips-care-rc1051410", "title": "World Malaria Day 2024: Everything About This Viral Fever in Children, Symptoms, Preventions, and More", "body": "World Malaria Day 2024: Malaria, a vector-borne disease transmitted by mosquito bites, remains a major global health concern, particularly among children in tropical and subtropical regions. Every year, World Malaria Day is observed to raise awareness of this life-threatening disease and how to prevent and properly care for malaria patients, particularly children and infants. The theme for World Malaria Day 2024 is \"Accelerate the fight against malaria for a more equitable world.\" The 15 countries with the highest number of malaria deaths are Nigeria, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, India, Mozambique, Ghana, Angola, Uganda, and others.\n\nMalaria spreads through the bite of an infected Anopheles mosquito. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), \"Malaria not only continues to endanger health and cost lives, but it also perpetuates a vicious cycle of inequity. People living in the most vulnerable situations, such as pregnant women, infants, children under the age of five, refugees, migrants, internally displaced people, and Indigenous Peoples, continue to be disproportionately affected.\"\n\nMalaria is characterized by a high fever, which frequently recurs in cycles, and severe cases may lead to nausea and vomiting\n\nChildren with malaria may have severe chills, shaking, and shivering.\n\nCommon symptoms include persistent headaches, which may be accompanied by vomiting.\n\nMalaria often causes children to feel extremely tired and weak.\n\nChildren often experience joint and muscle pain, which causes discomfort and restlessness.\n\nTo avoid mosquito bites while sleeping, make sure that children sleep under insecticide-treated bed nets, especially in malaria-endemic areas.\n\nApply DEET-based mosquito repellents to exposed skin surfaces, especially during outdoor activities in high-risk areas.\n\nRemove any stagnant water sources around your home, as they serve as breeding grounds for mosquitos.\n\nTo reduce mosquito bites, make sure your children wear long-sleeved shirts, pants, and socks.\n\nEncourage your children to drink plenty of fluids, such as water, electrolyte solutions, or oral rehydration solutions, to avoid dehydration caused by fever and sweat.\n\nEnsure that the child gets enough rest to help the immune system respond and recover.\n\nProvide light, nutritious meals to boost the child's energy and overall well-being. Fighting malaria requires maintaining good hygiene, a healthy lifestyle, and good dietary habits. Increase fluid intake, eat a well-balanced diet rich in nutrients, and consume foods that boost immunity such as fruits, nuts, and seeds. Also, include Vitamin D in your diet.", "source": {"uri": "jagrantv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "jagrantv"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8096080726", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "05:34:14", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T05:34:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T05:34:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://doctor.ndtv.com/living-healthy/world-malaria-day-2024-understanding-the-consequences-of-malaria-during-pregnancy-5518329", "title": "World Malaria Day 2024: Understanding The Consequences of Malaria During Pregnancy", "body": "Pregnant women are more likely to be susceptible to the illness due to their altered immune response\n\nMalaria is a fatal disease caused by the parasites of the plasmodium genus, transmitted to humans through the infectious bites of female mosquito Anopheles. Malaria remains a substantial public health concern, specifically in tropical and sub-tropical regions, where conditions are favourable for mosquito breeding. When it comes to pregnant women, malaria poses unique challenges, risks, and threats. Pregnant women are more likely to be susceptible to the illness due to their altered immune response, and the consequences can be severe for both the mother and the unborn child.\n\nThere are five types of parasites, but the most common and deadly in pregnancy are Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium vivax. These parasites can cross the placenta and impact the foetal development, leading to complications. Understanding the risks and implementing preventive measures is essential for protecting the pregnant women and their babies from dangers of malaria. Malaria can have critical risks to the pregnant ladies and their child. Some of the major risks associated with malaria are:\n\n1. Anaemia: the malaria parasites infect red blood cells, leading to their destruction. Pregnant women with malaria are at a higher risk of developing anaemia, which can result in fatigue, weakness, and a higher chance of postpartum haemorrhage.\n\n2. Low birth weight and preterm delivery: Infections during pregnancy can reduce foetal growth, resulting in low birth weight. Malaria is also associated with higher risk of preterm delivery, potentially causing complications in the baby's early development.\n\n3. Miscarriage and Stillbirth: Malaria increases the risk of miscarriage, especially during the first trimester. In severe cases, it can also lead to stillbirth, where the baby is born without any signs of life.\n\n4. Congenital Malaria: Parasites can cross the placenta and infect the baby, leading to congenital malaria. This condition cause fever, irritability, and poor feeding in newborns.\n\nPreventing malaria during pregnancy is crucial for the health of both the mother and the baby. Some of the preventive measures that pregnant ladies can take and consider are:\n\n1. Use of Insecticide-Treated Nets (ITNs): Sleeping under ITNs is one of the most effective ways to prevent mosquito bites and reduce the risk of Malaria. Pregnant women should ensure their nets are in good condition and properly used.\n\n2. Indoor Residual Spraying (IRS): This involves spraying insecticides on indoor walls to kill mosquitoes and reduce their population. IRS can significantly lower the risk of malaria transmission.\n\n3. Prophylactic Medication: In regions with high malaria transmission, pregnant women are often given antimalarial medication as a preventive measure. The specific drug and dosage depends on the local resistance patterns and trimesters of pregnancy.\n\n4. Avoidance of Mosquito-prone areas: Pregnant women should minimize exposure to areas with high mosquito activity, especially during peak biting times (dusk and dawn).\n\n5. Early detection and treatment: Pregnant women should seek medical attention if they experience malaria like symptoms. Early detection and appropriate treatment are critical to prevent complications.\n\nMalaria in pregnancy is a serious yet preventable concern. By adopting preventive measures and seeking early diagnosis, pregnant women can significantly reduce the risk of complications for themselves and their babies. Remember, knowledge and preventive measures are the best weapons in this fight. If you're planning a pregnancy or live in a malaria-prone area, talk to your doctor about creating a customized prevention plan.\n\n(Dr. Ravi N Sangapur, MD (Internal Medicine), Consultant Physician, HCG Hospital, Hubli)", "source": {"uri": "doctor.ndtv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Doctor.ndtv.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immune_response", "type": {"uri": "8097169518", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "17:17:48", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T17:17:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:17:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://easternmirrornagaland.com/nagaland-felicitates-asha-and-sw-on-world-malaria-day/", "title": "Nagaland Felicitates ASHA And SW On 'World Malaria Day' - Eastern Mirror", "body": "DIMAPUR -- Nagaland observed 'World Malaria Day' on Thursday on the theme \"Accelerating the fight against malaria for a more equitable world.' To mark the day, surveillance workers (SW) and accredited social health activists (ASHA) were felicitated for their outstanding performance during the programme.\n\n'World Malaria Day' is observed on April 25 every year to raise awareness about the global effort to control and ultimately eradicate malaria.\n\nDimapur: The 'World Malaria Day' in Dimapur was observed at the conference hall of the chief medical officer (CMO) with the deputy commissioner of Dimapur, Dr. Tinojongshi Chang, as the guest speaker.\n\nSpeaking at the programme, Dr. Chang congratulated the healthcare workers for their hard work in the fight against malaria and emphasised the importance of equitable access to healthcare.\n\nSeeking a collective effort to eliminate malaria, the DC stated that the disease has caused suffering and deaths for years due to mosquitoes. He also sought collaboration among various departments and civil society organisations to prevention malaria in rural areas.\n\nPeter Sangtam, DVBDC officer of Dimapur, stated that the main vision of the programme was to eliminate malaria from all the blocks by 2027 by interrupting transmission of malaria.\n\nMeanwhile, the CMO of Dimapur, Dr. Limatula Aier, highlighted on various activities and initiatives undertaken by the department to curb malaria effectively.\n\nThe surveillance workers (SW) and Accredited Social Health Activists (ASHA) were felicitated for their outstanding performance during the programme.\n\nMon: Mon district observed 'World Malaria Day' at the town council hall in Mon town with the additional deputy commissioner (ADC) of Mon, K Temjennaro Longkumer, as the special guest.\n\nSpeaking at the programme, the ADC stressed on maintaining sanitisation to combat vector borne diseases. She also urged the gathering to educate the public to maintain hygiene to prevent occurrence of malaria.\n\nSpeaking on the theme, Ngipnon from Edith Douglas School stated that malaria is not just a health issue but a social issue. She has sought collaborative effort to fight malaria.\n\nThe CMO of Mon, Dr. Imnapokim, informed that Mon district has nil report of malaria in the past three years. He encouraged the public to be more responsible and maintain vigilance against the disease.\n\nTwo ASHA and surveillance workers each from the district were felicitated on the occasion.\n\nTuensang: Tuensang district observed 'World Malaria Day' in the conference hall of the chief medical officer (CMO) in Tuensang town with the additional deputy commissioner (ADC), Thungchanbemo Tungoe, as the special guest.\n\nSpeaking on the programme, the ADC informed that Tuensang district has nil case of malaria till date and cautioned against complacency. He called upon the public to create awareness by cleaning their surroundings especially water stagnant area, using mosquito repellent and mosquito nets.\n\nThe CMO of Tuensang, Dr. NeisakhoKere, delivered the welcome address, while Yimliyangla Ong, DVBC officer of Tuensang, spoke on NVBDCP activities.\n\nWokha: The 'World Malaria Day' in Wokha was observed at the conference hall of the chief medical officer's (CMO) office.\n\nSpeaking at the programme, Dr. K William Humtsoe, district vector borne officer of Wokha, called upon to create awareness in the fight against the disease. He informed on the malaria activities such as community cleanup which included removal of mosquito breeding sites and distribution of long lasting insecticide nets (LLIN).\n\nThe CMO of Wokha, Dr. Zubenthung Kikon, urged the healthcare workers to sensitise the public on the treatment and testing facilities provided by the medical department, while Wezolo Medo, NVBDCP consultant of Wokha, gave a brief report on the malaria scenario in the district. He informed that only two cases were reported in 2023.\n\nAccredited Social Health Activists (ASHA) and Surveillance Workers (SW) were felicitated for their performance in malaria reporting in the district.\n\nLongleng: The 'World Malaria Day' programme in Longleng district was held at the office of the chief medical officer (CMO). The event coincided with the meeting of district task force.\n\nSpeaking at the programme, the district vector borne officer (DVBO), Dr. Tiameren Imchen, informed that Longleng district has recorded zero malaria cases since 2019. He also encouraged the malaria elimination team to monitor and supervise the whole district and respective health units to ascertain certification by DTF and to review and verify the reports to ensure its quality.\n\nThe EAC of Longleng, Imkongnukla Ao, stressed on the importance of sanitation and encouraged the public to use LLIN regularly, fill up the ditches and unwanted water collection sites in and around the locality.\n\nOn the occasion, best ASHA and surveillance workers were felicitated with certificates and cash prizes.\n\nReport stated that similar programmes were observed in all the 3 blocks under Longleng.\n\nMokokchung: Mokokchung district observed 'World Malaria Day' at the conference hall of the chief medical officer (CMO) in Mokokchung town.\n\nSpeaking on the occasion, the additional deputy commissioner (ADC) of Mokokchung, Chumlamo Humtsoe, lauded the Medical department and NVBDCP for their effort to eradicate malaria in the district. He encouraged the medical team to render valuable services especially to rural areas.\n\nImkummongba Nungtanger, DVBD consultant, presented the status of malaria, IEC/ BCC activities, national framework for malaria elimination and importance of case control in the district.\n\nDuring the programme, two best performing ASHAs and 2 best surveillance workers were facilitated.\n\nPhek: Phek district observed 'World Malaria Day' in the conference hall of the chief medical officer (CMO), Phek town, with the deputy commissioner of Phek, John Tsulise Sangtam, as the chief guest.\n\nSpeaking at the programme, the chief guest congratulated the healthcare workers for achieving zero malaria case and encouraged them to constantly maintain the status. He also emphasised on the importance of spreading awareness to the public on the preventive measures to control mosquitoes breeding to eliminate malaria from the district.\n\nHe further assured full support from the administration in carrying out awareness activities in the district.\n\nIn his keynote address, Dr. MC Longai Phom, deputy chief medical officer, highlighted the district data and its achievement. He also shared that coordination from other line departments could help to eliminate malaria in the district.\n\nTwo best ASHAs and surveillance workers each were felicitated with a certificate and "date": "2024-04-25", "textStart": 341, "textEnd": 349}], "sentiment": -0.01960784313725494, "wgt": 148, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-04-335135188", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "11:55:48", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T11:55:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T11:41:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/why-fight-against-malaria-having-114130200.html", "title": "Why the fight against malaria is having a 'Red Queen' moment", "body": "As Alice and the Red Queen run towards a chessboard in Lewis Carroll's childhood classic, the wind whistling in their ears, the little girl makes a curious discovery: despite running very fast for a very long time, she hasn't actually moved.\n\nThe Red Queen appears unfazed. \"Here, you see, it takes all the running you can do, to keep in the same place,\" she explains. \"If you want to get somewhere else, you must run twice as fast as that.\"\n\nFor malaria researchers and practitioners, this sensation feels all too familiar. Despite several exciting advances, efforts to tackle the parasitic pathogen have stalled since 2015: then, according to the World Health Organization (WHO), 586,000 people died from the disease; in 2022, it killed 608,000.\n\n\"It really does seem like a Red Queen scenario, we do an awful lot of running [to] make small steps forward,\" says Prof Chris Drakeley, a professor of infection and immunity at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine.\n\nThat's because both the malaria parasite and the mosquitoes which spread it are wily opponents, constantly evolving to evade efforts to wipe out the disease. \"Any organism, when you put pressure on it, will change,\" Prof Drakeley says. \"I think the challenge at the moment is really: how do we deal with these changes?\"\n\nThree biological threats are of particular concern to experts grappling to eradicate malaria: stealth parasites, super mosquitoes, and mounting resistance.\n\n\"Right now we are in this sort of turning point moment, where it could go either way,\" says Prof Olivo Miotto, a malaria genomics expert at the Mahidol-Oxford Tropical Medicine Research Unit in Bangkok.\n\nStealth parasites\n\nThe first issue affects diagnostics. In 2010, researchers in the Peruvian Amazon detected an unusual mutation: some parasites no longer had HRP2 proteins, which many lateral flow tests use to detect malaria. This meant cases could be missed, giving the disease - and the genetic quirk - space to circulate.\n\nSince then, the deletion has spread across continents. While prevalence estimates vary, a concerning hotspot has emerged in the Horn of Africa - some studies have suggested as many as 80 per cent of asymptomatic cases in Djibouti and Eritrea have could not be picked up by rapid diagnostics reliant on the HRP2 and HRP2 protein. In 2022, according to the WHO, 415.5 million such tests were sold worldwide.\n\n\"There's a different antigen [test] to pick this up, but it's not as well researched and developed,\" says Dr Stephen Woolley, an honorary clinical researcher and malaria specialist at the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine. \"WHO is trying to validate these newer tests... but I think this could be a really big challenge to global health and malaria control.\n\n\"We're seeing that in the Horn of Africa, and it's now spreading to Kenya and Uganda,\" he says, adding that doctors have also identified the issue in clinics in Britain. Earlier this week, the UK Health Security Agency said the number of malaria cases diagnosed here among travellers exceeded 2,000 for the first time since 2001.\n\nBut the deletion does not mean the malaria parasite is \"under an invisibility cloak\", says Prof Drakeley, as cases can still be diagnosed in the laboratory. He is optimistic that the issue - which affects only a tiny proportion of global malaria infections - can be contained, and that newer rapid diagnostics to solve it are on the horizon.\n\nSuper mosquitoes\n\nSuper mosquitoes have also emerged and appear to be driving an unexpected surge in malaria across the Horn of Africa. Combined with the changing parasite, the impact could be terrible.\n\n\"The genotype of the parasite, mixed with Anopheles stephensi [mosquito]... is a recipe for disaster potentially in Africa, and could make elimination extremely difficult,\" says Dr Woolley.\n\nUnlike the Anopheles gambiae mosquito, the most widespread carrier of malaria, the highly adaptable Anopheles stephensi thrives in urban areas and breeds almost anywhere - in a dirty puddle between slum shacks, a rubbish dump, or even water in an abandoned car tyre.\n\nIt also survives in high temperatures in dry seasons, when malaria transmission usually lulls.\n\nNative to parts of Asia and the Arabian peninsula, its arrival in Africa has triggered concerns that the burden of disease could shift from rural to urban areas. It was first spotted in Djibouti in 2012, and was a key driver of a 2,800 per cent surge over the next eight years.\n\nIt has since spread to countries including Ethiopia, Somalia and Nigeria, while the WHO has described it as a \"threat to malaria control and elimination\", especially in African megacities.\n\n\"There's clearly a concern around the arrival of the anopheles stephensi in Africa and the impact of that is still, in my view, extremely uncertain,\" says Prof Nick White, a professor at the Mahidol-Oxford Tropical Medicine Research Unit, who specialises in malaria.\n\n\"It's a worry because we have an increasing change in the demography in Africa, with a move from rural areas to cities. It follows that a city-dwelling mosquito would do quite well - but it's not a fantastic vector.\"\n\nBut with the stephensi, \"it feels like for once we are above the curve\", says Dr Jackie Cook, co-director of the Malaria Centre at the LSHTM. The vector was detected early, surveillance networks have been established, and vector control efforts are ramping up.\n\nResistance\n\nThe same cannot be said for drug and insecticide resistance, which have repeatedly emerged.\n\n\"We're a little bit slow at having new things coming through the pipeline, we never seem to be ahead of the curve,\" she warns. \"We're always waiting for something bad to happen, and then we react to it.\"\n\nThere are two forms of resistance: resistance among mosquitoes to insecticides, and resistance among parasites to antimalarial drugs.\n\nIn the WHO's latest malaria report, published in November, the agency warned that 87 per cent of countries have reported some resistance to pyrethroid-based insecticides, 82 per cent to organochlorines, 69 per cent of carbamates, and 60 per cent to organophosphates.\n\nThis problem has not emerged overnight - reduced efficacy of pyrethroid, which is used on bednets, was first noticed more than a decade ago. While there have been efforts to rotate or mix insecticides, it was not until last year that the WHO updated its recommendations to also use chlorfenapyr - the first insecticide in some 40 years, which grounds mosquitoes by causing their wings to spasm.\n\nThis has proven to be incredibly effective: a study earlier this month found that the rollout of the potent insecticide has prevented at least 13 million cases in Africa.\n\nDr Cook says the new insecticide coated bednets are \"fantastic\", but is concerned they will lull us into a false sense of security.\n\n\"It feels like we're all piling on chlorfenapyr - lots of companies are pivoting because it's been shown to be more effective, which creates more competition and brings prices down. But what's next? Will we find ourselves in the same situation 10 years down the line? There doesn't seem to be much else coming through the pipeline.\n\n\"We're spending all this money monitoring the situation, but we should have put a lot of that money into developing the new tools,\" Dr Cook adds. \"I think we've done things badly in terms of insecticide resistance. The concern is we do the same with drug resistance as well.\"\n\nThis would be a major blow. At the moment, doctors are predominantly reliant on artemisinin-based treatments to tackle malaria - between 2010 and 2022, more than four billion courses were delivered to clinics by manufacturers.\n\nCurrently, the WHO describes the status as \"partial resistance\" - drugs still work, just more slowly. But the issue is spreading, having jumped from the Greater Mekong Region where it was first noted, to Africa.\n\n\"We rely entirely on artemisinin combination treatments, of which there are over half a billion treatments given each year,\" says Prof White. \"If we lose these, we're in serious trouble - because despite all the large investments in antimalarial drug discovery in the past 20 years, we've been rather unsuccessful.\n\n\"There are new drugs that could save us - candidates from Novartis look most promising - but they are still three to five years away,\" he says.\n\nHe adds that efforts are underway to reduce the rise of resistance - such as using two other drugs alongside artemisinin, not just one, and encouraging people to finish their course. But this is likely only \"sticking a plaster\" on the issue - at some point, full resistance will spread.\n\nMost significant is the rollout of two new malaria vaccines: in July 2022 GSK's RTS,S shot, also known as Mosquirix, was approved, followed by Oxford University's R21 immunisation in December. Experts say these shots, which are around 75 per cent effective at preventing the disease in areas where transmission is seasonal, could save tens of thousands of children's lives every year.\n\n\"The vaccine is the latest 'shiny thing' for humans, but alone it's not going to end malaria transmission,\" says Prof Drakeley. \"But it will save lives... it's a nine per cent reduction in all cause mortality in children, that's massively impressive.\"\n\nOther exciting tools - from gene drive mosquitoes to spatial repellents for homes and buildings - are also emerging, with researchers describing it as an \"exciting time\" to be in the malaria field.\n\nCountries are also containing the disease: in 2023, Azerbaijan, Belize and Tajikistan all eliminated the parasitic pathogen, joining 40 other countries certified as malaria-free, while regions like southeast Asia - where the disease once thrived - now have minimal infections.\n\nYet there are concerns that the funding needed to replicate these successes is dwindling - according to analysis from Malaria No More and the Oxford Economics Group, the proportion of global research and development funding dedicated to malaria has fallen from $707m in 2019 to $604m in 2022.\n\n\"Governments, research institutions and funding organisations must keep their foot on the accelerator to continue fostering novel interventions and treatments to maintain a robust malaria pipeline for the future,\" says Gareth Jenkins, an executive director at Malaria No More UK. \"If we don't, this disease can thrive again.\"\n\nThere are other \"not very politically digestible\" issues too, says Prof White, \"such as incompetence, corruption, fabrication of data, wrong results - all those sorts of things that no one ever talks about, but are actually quite important\".\n\nAnd then there are the broader societal issues - including climate change, extreme weather events, conflict and mass migration - that could derail eradication efforts, providing opportunities for malaria to thrive and new obstacles to deliver services.\n\n\"The playground for this disease is basically social circumstances - it's poverty, lack of resources, lack of accessibility to the really basic health services,\" says Prof Miotto. \"And in that sense, the failure of rapid tests or partial artemisinin resistance makes little difference if you don't have any rapid tests, and you don't have any drugs. We can't lose sight of the basics.\"", "source": {"uri": "uk.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News UK"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sarah_newey@uk.news.yahoo.com", "name": "Sarah Newey", Africa suffers more from malaria than any other region, with 94% of cases and 95% of deaths occurring worldwide.\n\nTwo innovative malaria vaccines are being rolled out across the continent this year. Nadine Dreyer asks Jayshree Raman whether 2024 will be the year the continent makes significant progress towards defeating the disease.\n\nof RTS,S The vaccine was the first to target a parasite. It was developed by the Walter Reed Army Research Institute after his 30 years of intense research and approved by the World Health Organization in 2021.\n\nAfter decades of vaccine research, a second malaria vaccine was approved just two years after the RTS,S vaccine. {"uri": "8097089019", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "16:18:26", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T16:18:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T16:17:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://independent.ng/who-commemorates-world-malaria-day-urges-sustained-efforts-toward-elimination/", "title": "WHO Commemorates World Malaria Day, Urges Sustained Efforts Toward Elimination | Independent Newspaper Nigeria", "body": "ABUJA - Dr. Matshidiso Moeti, the WHO Regional Director for Africa, has underscored significant strides made in malaria control and elimination efforts globally, disclosing that over US$50 billion has been mobilized since 2000.\n\nThis investment has averted 2.1 billion malaria cases and 11.7 million deaths, leading to a 50% reduction in the malaria mortality rate despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic.\n\nSpeaking on the occasion of the 17th World Malaria Day under the theme \"Advancing health equity, gender equality and human rights,\" Dr. Moeti emphasized the need for continuous and equitable delivery of malaria services, especially to vulnerable populations such as children, pregnant women, and rural communities.\n\nDr. Moeti highlighted recent milestones in malaria elimination, including the certification of Cabo Verde in January 2024 and the approval of the R21/MatrixM malaria vaccine, which will be rolled out in 19 African countries this year alongside the RTS,S vaccine.\n\nWhile celebrating progress, Dr. Moeti acknowledged persistent challenges facing the African region, including extreme weather events, conflict, resource constraints, and biological threats.\n\nShe called for concerted efforts to address these challenges and ensure equitable access to malaria interventions.\n\nDr. Moeti reiterated WHO's commitment to supporting strategic initiatives such as the \"High Burden High Impact\" (HBHI) approach, which targets countries hardest hit by malaria with customized interventions based on local data.\n\nShe also emphasized the importance of innovation and research to develop new strategies and tools targeting vulnerable groups.\n\nAcknowledging the critical role of partnerships, Dr. Moeti thanked organizations such as the Global Fund, the US President's Malaria Initiative, and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation for their support in delivering malaria services.\n\nShe called for renewed political commitments and increased investments in malaria control to achieve a malaria-free Africa.\n\nIn conclusion, Dr. Moeti urged governments, affected communities, and partners to prioritize malaria control efforts, strengthen health systems, and accelerate progress toward achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).\n\nShe emphasized the importance of surveillance, monitoring, and evaluation systems to target interventions effectively and adapt services to the most at-risk groups.\n\nDr. Moeti expressed confidence that by working together, Africa can accelerate efforts to achieve a malaria-free future.", "source": {"uri": "independent.ng", "dataType": "news", "title": "Independent Newspapers Nigeria"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8096396473", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "09:09:29", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T09:09:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T09:08:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/world/health/2671558/", "title": "World Malaria Day 2024: Health Tips for Fast Recovery | - ExBulletin", "body": "2. A very effective way to prevent malaria infection while sleeping, especially in areas where malaria is endemic, is to use insecticide-coated bed nets. These nets create a physical barrier between people and mosquitoes, reducing the possibility of nighttime attacks. To avoid mosquito bites and malaria transmission as much as possible, nets must be installed correctly and without tears. Regular maintenance and replacement are also required to maintain the effectiveness of the net over time.\n\n3. Eliminate mosquito breeding sites: To prevent mosquito breeding, dump all standing water in containers around your home. This covers buckets, old tires, flower pots, and other containers that collect water.\n\n4. Use indoor residual spraying (IRS): If you live in an area where malaria transmission is high, you may consider using IRS, which sprays insecticide on the walls and ceilings of your home to kill mosquitoes. .\n\n5. Seek treatment as soon as possible. If you develop malaria symptoms such as fever, headache, chills, or vomiting, seek medical treatment immediately. If diagnosed and treated early, the disease will not spread.\n\n6. Stay in air-conditioned or well-screened accommodations: Mosquitoes can easily enter rooms through unsealed windows and doors, so stay away from accommodations that are not well-screened or air-conditioned. Please don't.\n\n7. To prevent malaria, talk to your health care provider about the best antimalarial drug options before visiting areas where malaria is endemic. Pay attention to the usage and dosage of medicines, and be sure to follow the prescribed medicines even after returning home.\n\nThe time it takes to recover from malaria varies from person to person and is influenced by factors such as your overall health and the strength of the infection. Anyone who has had malaria is offered the following general recovery advice:\n\n1. Finish your prescribed treatment period: Be sure to finish your antimalarial medication, even if you start feeling better before you finish your treatment period. This increases the chance that the parasite will be completely removed from the body.\n\n2. Rest: Give your body time to relax and heal. Malaria can affect your body, so get plenty of rest and avoid physically demanding activities until you are completely well.\n\n3. Drink plenty of fluids such as water, juices, and electrolyte solutions to keep your body hydrated and help remove toxins.\n\n4. Eat nutritious foods: Eat a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains to help your body heal and strengthen your immune system. Please concentrate on\n\n5. Take precautions to avoid future mosquito bites, such as applying insect repellent, sleeping under a mosquito net, and wearing protective clothing, especially if you live or visit a malaria-endemic area.\n\n6. According to him, the one billion pounds is added to the funds coming from other donors, to be managed by global funds to tackle malaria and other diseases in Nigeria.\n\nHe added that it was from that funding that payment for things like insecticide, treated bed nets, diagnostics testing for malaria and also for chemoprevention were made.\n\n\"There are some states in Nigeria where malaria is seasonal. Those are states where chemoprevention is used to prevent children from coming down with malaria.\n\n\"In those states, malaria spreads in a few months within a year, and during that period, there is a high level of malaria transmission in children, resulting in lots of deaths,\" he said.\n\nThe health adviser said that children in such states were usually given malaria drugs, whether or not they have malaria.\n\n\"These are part of measures by global fund that have significantly reduced the level of sicknesses and deaths in children,\" he stated.\n\nHe said that the UK was a big contributor to the global fund, which is currently supporting about 13 states in Nigeria. He listed the states to include; Adamawa, Delta, Gombe, Jigawa, Kaduna, Kano, Katsina, Kwara, Niger, Ogun, Osun, Yobe and Taraba.\n\n\"With the global funding support, there has been a significant reduction of malaria-related deaths in children in Nigeria.\n\n\"In 2008, the World Health Organisation (WHO) estimated that Nigeria had about 221, 000 malaria-related deaths. But by 2022, the figure was about 189 deaths.\n\n\"There is a significant reduction due to the intervention of global funds, even when there was an increase in the nation's population.\n\n\"Lots of {"uri": "8096808116", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "13:17:00", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T13:17:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T13:16:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.socialnews.xyz/2024/04/25/malaria-during-pregnancy-increases-neurological-risks-for-babies/", "title": "'Malaria during pregnancy increases neurological risks for babies'", "body": "New Delhi, April 25 (SocialNews.XYZ) Malaria during pregnancy poses significant risks to the brain development of babies, experts said on World Malaria Day on Thursday.\n\nWorld Malaria Day is observed every year on April 25, to spread awareness about the mosquito-borne life-threatening disease spread to humans by female Anopheles mosquitoes and caused by parasites of the Plasmodium genus: Plasmodium falciparum, P. vivax, P. ovale, P. malariae, and P. knowlesi. Of these P. falciparum is the most deadly parasite responsible for the majority of malaria-related deaths.\n\nThis year's theme is \"Accelerating the fight against malaria for a more equitable world\".\n\n\"Severe malaria infections, particularly with Plasmodium falciparum, during the first half of pregnancy, can lead to microcephaly and reduced uteroplacental blood flow, depriving the foetus of oxygen and nutrients. This can result in preterm birth, low birth weight, and even foetal death,\" Dr Sanjay Majumdar, Consultant Paediatrician, Bhailal Amin General Hospital, Vadodara, told IANS.\n\nWhile mild infections are less likely to cause immediate neonatal danger, they still carry the potential for long-term neurological consequences.\n\n\"Neurological hazards for newborns include intrauterine growth retardation, hypoxic brain injury, seizures, lower IQ, attention deficit hyperactivity disorders, and learning disabilities. These issues stem from the maternal inflammatory immune response affecting foetal brain development,\" Dr Majumdar said.\n\nTo mitigate the risks, regular antenatal clinic visits are crucial for early detection and treatment.\n\nTesting for malaria should be conducted promptly if the mother exhibits symptoms like fever or weakness.\n\n\"It's essential to monitor these children's development and academic achievements closely to address any potential deficits early on. By emphasising early detection, treatment, and ongoing support, we can mitigate the long-term neurological effects of malaria during pregnancy and promote healthier outcomes for both mothers and babies,\" the doctor said.\n\nThe World Health Organisation estimates that India has 15 million cases of malaria with 19,500-20,000 deaths annually.\n\nAlthough malaria is deadly, it is preventable and curable, Dr Abhishek Gupta, Consultant - Pediatric And Pediatric Intensivist, Manipal Hospital Gurugram, told IANS.\n\n\"The infection is caused by a parasite and does not spread from person to person,\" he noted.\n\nSymptoms range from fever, \u2060chills, \u2060and headache to fatigue, confusion, seizures, and difficulty in breathing. However, early detection and treatments can stop mild cases from getting worse. \"Malaria can be prevented by avoiding mosquito bites and by taking medicines. Talk to a doctor about taking medicines such as chemoprophylaxis before travelling to areas where malaria is common,\" Dr Gupta said.\n\nHe also suggested using mosquito nets when sleeping in places where malaria is present; using mosquito repellents (containing DEET, IR3535, or Icaridin) after dusk; and wearing protective clothing.", "source": {"uri": "socialnews.xyz", "dataType": "news",
